The blade sliced the water with a sound like tearing silk, a clean rip in the morning's silence. Liam pulled, his whole body a coiled spring releasing its tension in one fluid, powerful motion. The scull, a fragile needle of carbon fibre, surged forward across the Chesterfield Canal. Dawn was a rumour of pale grey and pink staining the eastern sky, and the air held the raw, damp chill of a Derbyshire spring. Mist clung to the water's surface in lazy drifts, shrouding the banks and turning the distant, iconic twist of the crooked spire into a ghostly smudge on the horizon. Out here, there was only the rhythm. The catch, the drive, the finish, the recovery. The rhythmic gasp of his own breath. The squeak of the oarlocks. For ten years, this had been his sanctuary, his church, his proving ground. The water didn't care about your day job or your family troubles; it only cared about power, technique, and endurance.

But this morning, another rhythm fought for purchase in his mind. A melody. A simple, soulful hook from an old Sam Cooke tune that had snagged in his brain and refused to let go. He found himself humming it on the recovery, a low baritone rumble in his chest that was lost to the wind. The song was a secret, a small, warm thing he carried inside him. Rowing was for his body, for the sinew and muscle he had spent a decade building. Singing was for whatever was left over. It was the part of him that didn't fit the mould of a six-foot-three, fourteen-stone athlete who could pull a two-kilometre erg test in a time that made other men weep. It was a secret garden he tended to in the shower, in his car, and on the rare Tuesday nights he had the courage to go to the open mic at The Rutland Arms.

He let the boat glide, the hiss of the hull on the water slowing as he sat up, wiping a bead of sweat from his brow with the back of his wrist. He pulled his phone from its waterproof pouch. The screen was cold against his thumb. He opened the email again, for what must have been the twentieth time since it had arrived last night. The subject line still gave him a jolt, a fizz of something that felt dangerously like hope.

*Subject: Voice of the Peaks - Grand Final Confirmation*

*Dear Liam Kenna,*
*Following your incredible performance in the semi-final, we are absolutely delighted to invite you to compete in the Grand Final of Voice of the Peaks 2024...*

It was real. The words hadn't rearranged themselves overnight into a rejection. He, Liam Kenna, the quiet lad from Whittington Moor who spent most of his life going backwards down a canal, was in the final of a proper singing competition. Not just a pub karaoke night with a prize of a gallon of ale, but a real, televised-on-a-local-channel, sponsored-by-a-regional-car-dealership competition. The thought was so absurd, so far removed from the cold reality of his aching quads and blistered hands, that he almost laughed out loud. He’d entered on a whim, egged on by his sister, Claire, after she’d filmed him on her phone singing at a family barbecue. He’d sent in the grainy video of him murdering—or so he thought—Otis Redding’s ‘(Sittin' On) The Dock of the Bay’, and somehow, against all odds, they’d invited him to an audition.

The early rounds had been a blur of nervous energy. He’d stood backstage in his borrowed suit, feeling like a bear in a doll's house amongst the slender, confident drama school kids and the seasoned pub singers with their worn-out guitars. Then he’d walked on stage, the lights hot on his face, and opened his mouth. And the voice that came out always surprised him. It was deeper, richer, than his speaking voice, a resonant sound that seemed to come from the soles of his feet. It felt like the only time he was ever truly expressing the entirety of himself. The judges, a panel of local radio DJs and a former West End performer who’d retired to the Peak District, had been visibly taken aback. ‘Where did *that* voice come from, young man?’ one of them had asked, peering at him over her glasses as if he were some sort of geological anomaly.

"He's here. The phantom of the canal."

Liam jolted, nearly dropping his phone in the water. Dave, his coach, was standing on the towpath, arms crossed over his chest, his stocky frame silhouetted against the brightening sky. His face, weathered and perpetually unimpressed, was fixed on Liam.

"Daydreaming, Kenna? Or admiring your reflection?" Dave's voice was gravelly, a product of too many years of shouting encouragement through a megaphone into the wind.

"Just checking the time, coach," Liam lied, quickly stowing the phone. He grabbed the oars, his knuckles white.

"The time is 'time to put some bloody work in'," Dave grunted. "Your splits for that last five hundred were lazy. Your head's not in the boat. The Northern Regatta is in three weeks. Manchester will eat you alive if you're pulling like that. I want three sets of five-hundred-metre sprints. And I want to see the water churn."

Liam nodded, his jaw tight. "Yes, coach."

He didn't argue. You didn't argue with Dave. The man had coached rowers to national championships. He lived and breathed the sport, and he expected the same monastic devotion from his top athletes. He would not, Liam knew, understand a singing competition. To Dave, anything that wasn't geared towards making the boat go faster was a frivolous, pointless distraction. A weakness.

As he turned the scull and paddled back to his starting point, the conflict churned inside him, a messy counter-rhythm to the smooth mechanics of the stroke. Rowing was his life, the bedrock of his identity. It had given him discipline, strength, a community. He owed everything to it, and to Dave. But the singing… the singing was a new, thrilling discovery. It was a door opening into a room in his own house that he never knew existed. The Grand Final was in Sheffield, at the City Hall, in two weeks’ time. Two weeks. He had to choose a song, practice, figure out what to wear. He had to drive there. His car, a battered fifteen-year-old Ford Fiesta he’d nicknamed ‘The Biscuit Tin’ for its tendency to rattle, would have to be coaxed into making the journey over the moors.

He took a deep breath, the cold air burning his lungs. For now, he would row. He would make the water churn for Dave. He would give the canal the power it demanded. But as he coiled his body for the first sprint, it wasn't the thought of the finish line at the regatta that spurred him on. It was the memory of the stage lights, the hush of the crowd, and the first, terrifying, wonderful note of a song taking flight.

The boathouse smelled of damp lycra, river water, and industrial floor cleaner. It was a familiar, comforting smell to Liam, the scent of hard work and belonging. He racked his boat with the practiced ease of long habit, his muscles humming with the pleasant ache of exertion. Other members of the club were arriving now, a trickle of bodies in brightly coloured technical gear, their voices echoing in the cavernous space.

"Morning, Liam. Good session?" It was Mark, another single sculler, a wiry accountant who rowed with a ferocious intensity that belied his day job.

"Morning. Yeah, not bad," Liam replied, towelling his hair dry. "Dave was on the warpath, as usual."

Mark chuckled. "Tells you he cares. When he stops shouting, that’s when you need to worry." He paused, lowering his voice slightly. "Heard a rumour on the club WhatsApp. Something about you being on the telly?"

Liam felt a hot blush creep up his neck. He’d hoped to keep it quiet for a bit longer, to let the idea settle in his own mind before it became club gossip. But news, like water, always found a way to leak out. "Ah. Yeah. Sort of. Local telly, maybe."

Mark's eyes widened. "Don't be modest, mate! The Voice of the Peaks! My missus loves that show. She said there was a big lad from Chesterfield who sang like an angel. Didn't realise it was you! That's brilliant! What are you gonna sing in the final?"

The question hung in the air. Liam hadn't even let himself think that far ahead. The pressure of it suddenly felt immense. "Not sure yet. Got to pick something."

"Well, whatever it is, you'll smash it," Mark said, clapping him on the shoulder with a wet hand. "Just don't forget us little people when you're famous."

The encounter left Liam feeling strangely exposed. The two halves of his life, the rower and the singer, were beginning to collide, and he wasn't sure how to manage the impact. He finished changing in a haze, nodding and murmuring vague pleasantries to his clubmates, all the while feeling their curious glances. He was no longer just Liam Kenna, the club's strongest sculler. He was a novelty. The Singing Rower.

He escaped the boathouse and got into The Biscuit Tin. The engine turned over with a phlegmy cough and a shudder that vibrated through the driver’s seat. The dashboard lit up like a Christmas tree with warning lights that he’d long since learned to ignore. As long as the oil light and the engine temperature light stayed off, he considered it a victory. He pulled out of the car park, the radio crackling to life. A generic pop song filled the small car. He turned it off. He needed to think.

Driving through the familiar streets of Chesterfield, past the market stalls being set up and the morning commuters heading to the train station, he felt a disconnect. This was his world. Solid, predictable, real. The singing competition felt like a dream he was having, and he was terrified of waking up. What if he made a fool of himself? What if he got on that big stage and his voice cracked? What if the judges who had been so kind before were suddenly critical? The fear was a cold knot in his stomach, a stark contrast to the elation he'd felt just a few hours earlier. Rowing had taught him to manage physical pain and exhaustion, but this... this was different. This was a fear of failure that was purely about his soul.

He pulled up outside his small terraced house. His sister’s car was parked outside. Claire must have dropped off her son, Leo, for him to look after while she was at work. Liam smiled. Leo, his seven-year-old nephew, would be a welcome distraction. The boy lived entirely in the moment, his world a whirlwind of Lego, football, and endless questions.

He opened the front door to the immediate assault of a small, human hurricane.

"Uncle Liam! You promised we could go to the park! And you said you'd show me your medals again! Did you win today? Did you beat everyone? Mum said you're going to be a pop star!"

Leo was already dressed in a full, slightly-too-large football kit, and was bouncing on the balls of his feet with an energy Liam envied. Claire was in the kitchen, making toast. She was two years older than Liam, a primary school teacher with a practical, no-nonsense attitude, but with the same kind eyes as their late mother.

"Morning, superstar," she said, grinning at him. "Surviving the hype?"

Liam grunted, ruffling Leo’s hair. "Barely. Mark at the club already knows. I feel like a prize pig at a country fair."

"Get used to it," Claire said, handing him a mug of tea. "I put it on the school's parent Facebook group. The whole of Brampton is rooting for you."

"You what?" Liam choked on his tea. "Claire! Why would you do that?"

"Because I'm proud of you, you big idiot!" she retorted, her expression softening. "For years, all you've done is that bloody rowing. Up at five every morning, protein shakes, blisters, aches and pains. You never do anything just for fun. This is for fun. And you're brilliant at it. You need to let yourself enjoy it."

"It's not just for fun anymore, is it?" Liam said, his voice quiet. "It's the final. There's a prize. People are... watching."

Claire came and put an arm around his broad shoulders. "Listen to me. You've been singing since you were Leo's age. Mum used to say you sang before you could talk properly. You used to stand on that hearth, remember? Using the TV remote as a microphone, singing along to her Dusty Springfield records. Her heart would have burst seeing you on that stage."

The mention of their mum struck a chord deep inside him. She had been the music in their house. After she’d passed away from cancer five years ago, the house had fallen silent in more ways than one. His dad, a man of few words at the best of times, had retreated further into himself. For Liam, singing the old songs they’d shared had become a way of keeping her close, a private conversation with her memory. Maybe that’s what this was all about.

"Just… don't let Dave from the rowing club find out," Liam mumbled into his mug.

Claire laughed, a bright, clear sound. "Oh, he'll be fine. Might do him good to realise there's more to life than messing about in boats. Now," she said, turning her attention to her son, "Leo, be good for your uncle. No breaking anything expensive. And Liam," she fixed him with a mock-serious glare, "you need to pick a song for the final. A proper showstopper. No sad ballads. Something that'll get them on their feet."

As she left for work, leaving a trail of perfume and cheerful chaos in her wake, Liam was left alone with his nephew and his thoughts. A showstopper. The words echoed in his head. He looked around the small living room, at the mantelpiece crowded with rowing trophies and a single, faded photograph of his smiling mother. He had two weeks to become a showman. Two weeks to bridge the chasm between the silent, powerful man in the boat and the soulful singer he was only just beginning to know. The prospect was, in a word, terrifying. And in another, completely and utterly exhilarating.The silence that followed Claire's departure was immediately filled by Leo, who began using the living room rug as a makeshift football pitch, commentating on his own imaginary game in a breathless whisper. "And Kenna shoots... he scores! The crowd goes wild!" Liam watched him, a faint smile on his lips. He sank into the worn armchair, the springs groaning in protest under his weight. His body felt heavy, anchored by fatigue, but his mind was a frantic buzz of conflicting demands. The regatta. The final. Dave's gravelly voice. Claire's cheerful encouragement. His mother’s smile. It was too much.

"Can we see the medals now?" Leo abandoned his game, skidding to a halt by the arm of the chair and looking up at him with wide, pleading eyes. "Please? The shiny ones."

"Alright, alright, you little monster," Liam sighed, heaving himself up. It was a familiar ritual. He opened the glass-fronted cabinet where his prizes were kept. Dozens of them, mostly gold and silver, hung from ribbons or stood on small wooden plinths. He took down the heaviest, a gold medal from the National Championships two years prior. "This one's from when we won the coxless fours," he explained, placing the cool, heavy metal in Leo’s small hands. The boy’s eyes were round with awe. "It was the hardest race I've ever done. It was raining so hard you could barely see the finish line, and my hands were so raw I could feel the oar through the blisters." He spoke of the race with a detached reverence, as if describing a natural disaster he had survived. This, he understood. The pain, the burn, the reward. It was a simple, brutal equation.

Leo traced the embossed crest on the medal. "Is being a pop star harder than this?" he asked, his voice full of genuine curiosity. Liam was taken aback. He looked from the medal in Leo’s hand—a tangible record of a decade of gruelling, single-minded effort—to the memory of the stage, a fleeting, terrifying, thirty-minute blur.

"I don't know, mate," he said honestly. "It's… different." He put the medal away, the click of the cabinet door sounding unnervingly final. "In a race, you know what you've got to do. You pull as hard as you can. If you're strong enough and your technique's good enough, you win. On stage… you can do everything right and people still might not like it. It’s not about how strong you are."

"But they do like it! Mum said you made Mrs. Higgins from next door cry, but in a good way," Leo insisted. "What song are you going to sing? Is it the one about the boat?" He meant '(Sittin' On) The Dock of the Bay'. Liam shook his head. "No, Claire's right. It needs to be something… bigger. A showstopper." The word felt foreign and ridiculous in his mouth. He wasn't a showman; he was a sculler. He moved backwards to go forwards. He faced away from where he was going. His entire sporting life was an exercise in quiet, introverted propulsion.

He sat back down and scrolled through his phone's music library, a curated collection of soul, blues, and old-school R&B that was a world away from the aggressive punk and rock that fuelled his teammates' workouts. He needed something that had power but also vulnerability. Something that could build, that could tell a story. He skimmed past Al Green, past Bill Withers. Then his thumb hovered over an album cover. Otis Redding again. But not the gentle melancholy of 'Dock of the Bay'. He tapped on 'Try a Little Tenderness'.

The song started soft and gentle, a simple declaration. Liam closed his eyes, listening. He knew every inflection, every breath. Then came the build. The horns kicking in, the tempo increasing, Redding’s voice cracking with raw, pleading emotion, building and building until it became a volcanic eruption of pure soul. It wasn't just a song; it was a three-and-a-half-minute emotional storm. It was technically demanding, vocally athletic, and utterly exposing. It was, he realised with a jolt of fear and excitement, a showstopper. It was perfect.

"Oh, young woman, they're so sweet..." he sang quietly, just under his breath, his deep voice barely a murmur. Leo's head popped up. "Sing it louder!" he demanded. Liam glanced at the closed curtains, a habitual secrecy taking over. But then he looked at his nephew’s expectant face, and at the photo of his mother on the mantelpiece, and something inside him loosened. He took a breath and sang the line again, this time letting his voice fill the small room. It felt good. It felt right. By the time he reached the explosive final section, he was on his feet, using a rolled-up magazine as a microphone, belting out the "Got to, got to, got to!" part with a passion that made Leo whoop with delight and start dancing around the coffee table. For a moment, he wasn't Liam the Rower or Liam the Finalist. He was just a man singing in his living room, his heart full, sharing a moment of pure, unadulterated joy with the small boy who idolised him. The music faded, leaving him breathless, his chest heaving, a wide grin spreading across his face. This was what Claire meant. This was for fun. This was for him. This was for her.The euphoria of the living room performance evaporated in the harsh fluorescent light of the club’s gym. The next few days fell into a brutal, familiar pattern. Pre-dawn sessions on the water, followed by punishing workouts on the rowing machines in the evening. The ergometer became his penitent's stool. He would strap his feet in, set the monitor for a two-thousand-metre piece, and pull. The fan whirred like a jet engine, the chain rattled, and the digital numbers on the screen became his entire world: split time, stroke rate, power output. But now, the machine had a soundtrack. The slow, soulful intro of ‘Try a Little Tenderness’ timed itself perfectly to his warm-up strokes. The explosive, desperate pleading of the song’s climax became the internal roar that accompanied his final sprint, his legs burning with lactic acid, his vision tunnelling.

Dave watched him like a hawk. The coach would stand with his arms crossed, his gaze flicking between Liam's strained face and the unforgiving numbers on the monitor. He didn’t say much, which was more unnerving than his usual bellowing. He’d just circle the machine, his presence a heavy weight, occasionally tapping the screen. “Power’s fluctuating, Kenna. Your drive is inconsistent. One stroke you’re a god, the next you’re a tourist on a pedalo. Where’s your head at?” Liam, gasping for air, his throat raw, could only shake his head and try to focus. But focusing meant choosing one rhythm over the other, and his mind refused to cooperate. The rower and the singer were at war, and his body was the battlefield.

After one particularly gruelling session, where his final five-hundred-metre split was two seconds slower than his personal best, Dave followed him to the water fountain. "Alright, Liam. Out with it." The coach’s voice was low, devoid of its usual bluster. It was the voice he used for serious conversations, the one that could cut through any excuse. "Something's off. You're strong, you're fit, but you're not here." He tapped his own temple. "You're somewhere else. Family okay? Work?"

Liam let the cold water run over his hands, stalling. This was the moment. The moment to tell him, to explain the absurd, wonderful, terrifying thing that had happened. But the words wouldn't form. He pictured Dave's face, the inevitable dismissal, the disappointment. To Dave, this would be a betrayal of everything they had worked for. It would be a weakness. "Just tired, coach," he mumbled, not meeting his eye. "Not sleeping well."

Dave let out a long, slow breath, a sigh of profound frustration. "Well, you'd better get it sorted. The regatta is everything we've aimed for this season. To make sure you’re ready, I've booked the senior squad into a full immersion training camp at Holme Pierrepont. Starts Friday next week. We drive down after work. Two solid days. No phones, no family, no distractions. Just us, the water, and the work. I need your head completely in the boat, son. Completely."

The words hit Liam like a physical blow. Friday next week. The Grand Final was on the Saturday. In Sheffield. Holme Pierrepont was in Nottingham, a good hour's drive away in the wrong direction. The carefully constructed wall separating his two lives had just been demolished by a wrecking ball. He felt a wave of nausea. He just nodded dumbly, the lie he’d told moments before trapping him. "Yeah. Okay, coach. Sounds good."

The drive home in The Biscuit Tin was a journey through a fog of panic. The conflict was no longer a philosophical one; it was a logistical nightmare. He couldn't be in two places at once. He couldn't serve two masters, especially not when one was as demanding as Dave and the other was as seductive as a sold-out auditorium. He parked on a quiet lane overlooking the town, the crooked spire just visible through the dusk, and killed the engine. He pulled out his phone and played the Otis Redding track. He tried to sing along, to find that soaring power he’d discovered in his living room. But his throat was tight, constricted by anxiety. The notes that had flown so freely were now caged in his chest, weak and breathless. He wasn't a showstopper. He was a fraud who was about to let everyone down.

He didn't go home. Instead, he drove straight to Claire's house on the other side of town. He found her in the garden, patiently trying to untangle a set of solar-powered fairy lights while Leo directed her from a small plastic chair. She took one look at his face and set the tangled mess down. "Oh dear," she said. "That's your 'world-is-ending' face. I haven't seen that since you accidentally snapped one of Dave's precious carbon-fibre oars."

In a torrent of words, he explained the situation. The training camp. Dave’s ultimatum. The impossibility of it all. "I have to choose," he finished, slumping onto the garden bench. "And I don't know how. If I miss the camp, I'm letting the whole squad down. Dave will probably kick me out of the first boat. My season will be over. But if I don't go to the final..." He trailed off, unable to voice the alternative. To give up on the singing felt like cutting out a part of himself.

Claire listened, her brow furrowed in concentration. She picked up a stray football and bounced it on her knee, a habit she had when she was thinking hard. "Right," she said finally, her tone shifting from sympathetic sister to military strategist. "This isn't a choice. It's a scheduling problem. We're not choosing, we're managing." She started pacing on the small patch of lawn. "You go to the camp on Friday. You do the sessions. You tell Dave you have a… a family commitment you can’t get out of on Saturday evening. A christening. A cousin's wedding. Something boring he can't argue with."

"He'll know I'm lying," Liam groaned. "He can smell a lie from the other side of the canal."

"He won't care, as long as you're there for the important sessions," she countered, waving a dismissive hand. "So, you do the Saturday morning session. You give it everything you've got. Then you get in your car at, say, two o'clock. You drive to Sheffield. You check into a cheap hotel I'll find for you. You have a shower, you put on the new suit we are going to buy you, and you go to the City Hall. You walk on that stage, you sing your heart out, and you win the whole damn thing. Then," she took a deep breath, "you get back in your car, you drive back to Nottingham, get three hours sleep, and you're back on the water for the Sunday morning time trial. Simple."

Liam stared at her as if she had just suggested he row to the moon. The plan was ludicrous, a punishing marathon of driving, stress, and sleep deprivation that would leave him wrecked for both events. It was a recipe for spectacular, public failure on two separate fronts. "Claire, that's insane. I'll be exhausted. My voice will be shot. I won't be able to row the next day. I'll crash the car. I'll… I'll fail at both."

She stopped pacing and came to stand in front of him, her expression fierce with a belief he couldn't begin to muster for himself. "Liam Kenna, since when have you ever backed down from something because it was hard? You get up at five in the morning to train in the freezing rain. You've rowed until your hands bled. You push your body to its absolute limit every single day for a piece of metal on a ribbon. This is just another race. It's longer, and a bit more complicated, but it's the same thing. You just have to grit your teeth and pull."Claire’s words hung in the evening air, a blueprint for a miracle or a disaster. Liam stared at her, his mind reeling. The sheer audacity of the plan was breathtaking. It was a house of cards built on a lie, a punishing physical ordeal, and the reliability of a fifteen-year-old Ford Fiesta. Every rational instinct, every ounce of the disciplined caution that rowing had beaten into him, screamed that it was impossible. He would be spreading himself too thin, guaranteeing failure on all fronts. He would be a subpar rower and a hoarse, exhausted singer.

"It won't work," he said, the words heavy with defeat. "My body won't take it. The drive, the lack of sleep... I'll be useless for the time trial on Sunday. Dave will see right through it." He imagined his coach's disappointed, flinty gaze as he posted a sluggish time, the quiet 'I told you so' that would follow. The thought made his stomach clench. "And the singing… how can I sing a song like that, a song that needs everything you've got, when I'm running on empty?"

Claire stopped her pacing and took the football from Leo, who had been watching their exchange with the solemn intensity of a referee. She tucked it under her arm. "You're thinking like a rower, Liam. You're looking at the splits, the timings, the energy expenditure. You're not factoring in the one thing that rowing doesn't measure." She tapped her chest. "Heart. Adrenaline. The buzz you'll get from walking on that stage. That will carry you. That will be your fuel. Remember when Mum used to say you had more grit than sense? This is one of those times. You just have to decide if you have the guts to try."

She was right. He did think in numbers and physical limits. Rowing was a science of pain management and power curves. But singing… singing was alchemy. It was turning breath and memory into something that could make a stranger feel an emotion. He looked at his sister's determined face, so like their mother's in that moment, and felt a flicker of her insane optimism. What was the alternative? To call the competition organisers and withdraw? To tell them the quiet lad from Whittington Moor with the surprisingly big voice had to go to a training camp instead? The thought was unbearable. It felt like turning his back on that secret garden he’d tended for so long, letting all the flowers wither.

"A christening?" he asked, his voice barely a whisper. The lie felt sticky and unpleasant in his mouth.

Claire’s face broke into a triumphant grin. "Exactly. Your second cousin, once removed. On your dad's side. Incredibly devout family. Utterly unmissable. Dave won’t know any different. Now, first things first, we're going suit shopping tomorrow. You can't sing a showstopper looking like you're about to unblock a drain."

The following Saturday, Liam found himself standing awkwardly in the men's department of a Debenhams in Sheffield, feeling like an overgrown bear that had wandered into a haberdashery. The world of slim-fit trousers and tailored jackets was utterly alien to him. His wardrobe consisted of technical sportswear, work jeans, and a handful of check shirts. Claire, however, was in her element, pulling jackets from rails with ruthless efficiency. "No, not double-breasted, it'll make you look like a wardrobe," she muttered, discarding one option. "That one's too shiny, you'll look like a cruise ship entertainer." She finally thrust a dark charcoal suit at him. "Try this."

He retreated to the changing room, the space feeling laughably small. He wrestled his way into the crisp shirt and trousers, his broad shoulders and thick thighs straining against the unfamiliar fabric. When he finally put on the jacket and looked in the mirror, he barely recognised the man staring back. The suit was well-cut, slimming his frame and giving him a silhouette that was less 'brute force' and more ' quiet authority'. The charcoal fabric complimented his dark hair and the deep blue of the shirt Claire had chosen brought out the colour of his eyes. For the first time, he saw a glimmer of the man who could walk onto the stage at the City Hall. He wasn't just Liam the rower in borrowed clothes; he was someone else. A performer. The idea sent a nervous thrill right through him. He stepped out. Claire’s hand flew to her mouth. "Oh, Liam," she breathed. "You look... incredible. Mum would have loved this." The simple, heartfelt words were the only validation he needed.

The lie was the hardest part. He cornered Dave on Tuesday, after a brutal session on the water where he’d pushed himself to the point of seeing stars, determined to prove his commitment before he confessed his fictional family obligation. The coach was wiping down a boat, his movements methodical. Liam cleared his throat. "Coach, can I have a word?" Dave grunted an affirmative, not looking up. "It’s about the training camp. On Saturday," Liam began, his heart thumping against his ribs. "I’ve got a family thing I can’t get out of. A christening. In the evening. I can do the morning sessions, no problem, but I’ll have to leave in the afternoon."

Dave stopped wiping. He slowly straightened up and turned to face Liam, his eyes narrowed. He was silent for a long, agonising moment, his expression unreadable. "A christening," he repeated, the words flat. It wasn't a question. Liam nodded, his mouth dry. He braced himself for the explosion, the accusations, the dismissal. But it didn't come. Dave just looked at him, a flicker of something—disappointment, maybe even hurt—in his gaze. "Your attendance at family events has never been a problem before, Kenna." He picked up a rag and tossed it into a bucket with a wet slap. "Fine. Be there for the morning. I want two faultless sessions out of you. And you be back on that water at seven a.m. Sunday for the time trial. And you had better not be tired. Your cousin’s soul might be saved on Saturday, but your place in this boat won’t be if you pull a lazy time. Am I clear?"

"Crystal, coach," Liam said, the relief so profound it almost buckled his knees. He had his permission, conditional though it was. But Dave’s final look, a long, searching stare, left him feeling cold. The coach knew something was up. He just didn’t know what. The lie now felt less like a clever piece of scheduling and more like a debt that would be called in at 7 a.m. on Sunday morning.

Liam stood for a moment, the finality of the act washing over him. He had made his choice, and the consequences were real and immediate. Liam stood in the car park, the morning sun feeling unnaturally bright and hostile on his face. The official contract from the Edale festival arrived in his inbox a few days later, a stark, professional document that made it all terrifyingly real. A forty-five-minute set on the main stage. He thought of the open mic night, of the easy confidence of the house guitarist. Phil, the host, had called him Jamie. With a sense of leaping into the void, Liam found the number for The Rutland Arms and asked for him.

He met Jamie in a different pub, a musician's haunt in the centre of Sheffield with sticky floors and a jukebox full of classic rock. Jamie was younger than him by at least ten years, with bright, intelligent eyes and the restless energy of someone whose fingers were always itching to play. Liam, feeling like a giant in the small, crowded room, explained the situation, the words feeling clunky and inadequate. He felt like a fraud, a rower playing dress-up in a musician's world. But Jamie listened with an infectious enthusiasm, his eyes lighting up when Liam mentioned Edale. "Mate, that's huge! Their main stage is legendary. So, you need a band?" Liam nodded, feeling a blush creep up his neck. "I don't know the first thing about it." Jamie grinned, a wide, easy smile. "Don't worry about that. That's the easy part. I know a rhythm section that's tighter than a submarine door. A bassist, Steve, and a drummer, Chloe. They're amazing. We've been looking for a proper singer, someone with real pipes, not another indie kid mumbling into his fringe." The casual compliment landed with surprising force. *A proper singer.* It was a validation from a world he was desperate to belong to. "Let's have a jam," Jamie said, pulling a notebook from his pocket. "Let's see what we can build."

Their first rehearsal was in a dingy, soundproofed room above a Sheffield pub, a space that smelled of stale beer, old carpets, and electricity. It was chaotic and loud. Chloe, the drummer, sat behind a battered kit, a whirlwind of focused energy, while Steve, the bassist, stood quietly, a calm anchor in the sonic storm, his fingers dancing effortlessly on the fretboard. Liam felt utterly out of his depth. He was used to silence and solitude, to the clean, straight lines of a race course. This was a messy, collaborative art, a conversation shouted in a language of chords and drum fills. They tried 'Try a Little Tenderness' first, and it was a train wreck. Liam was used to singing it with a polished house band that followed his lead; this was different. This was a negotiation. They stopped and started, the song falling apart as they struggled to find a common rhythm. Liam felt a surge of panic, a feeling of total incompetence. But Jamie just laughed. "Alright, let's take it from the build-up. Chloe, watch him. He sings like a boxer. Follow his breathing." They tried again. Jamie hit the chords, Chloe came in with a thunderous, rolling fill, and Steve locked into a groove that was a solid, pulsing heartbeat. Liam took a breath and sang, and this time, the band was with him. They weren't just backing him; they were lifting him, pushing him, answering his vocal lines with their own musical declarations. He felt the raw power of it, a force far greater than his own, a surge of energy that was like catching a perfect stroke with three other rowers in perfect sync. It was a different kind of boat, a different kind of crew, but the feeling of shared, explosive power was the same.

He drove home from the rehearsal late that night, his ears ringing and his throat raw from pushing his voice over the joyful noise of a full band. The Biscuit Tin’s radio was off, the silence a welcome relief. He was tired, but it was a new kind of tired, a creative exhaustion that buzzed with energy rather than leaden fatigue. He pulled over at his usual vantage point, the quiet lane overlooking the sleeping town. For weeks, this spot had been a place of turmoil and difficult decisions. Tonight, it felt different. He looked out at the familiar pattern of orange streetlights and dark rooftops, the crooked spire a steadfast silhouette against a starry sky. He thought of the rowing club, of Dave, of the black line through his name. The ache of that loss was still there, a faint, phantom limb of a past life. But it was no longer the dominant feeling. It was being replaced by the thrill of the new, the terror and excitement of the path he was now on. He was no longer a rower mourning his past. He was a singer, and he had a festival to prepare for. He had a band to lead. He put the car in gear and drove towards home, a new set of rhythms playing in his head, a new set of proving grounds waiting.The weeks leading up to the Edale festival took on a rhythm of their own, a vibrant, chaotic cadence that was a world away from the metronomic precision of his rowing life. Liam’s mornings were no longer defined by the shrill scream of a 5 a.m. alarm and the cold shock of canal water. He still rose early, the discipline of a decade too deeply ingrained to abandon, but his purpose had shifted. Instead of the towpath, he took to the trails of the Linacre Woods, running not against a stopwatch but for the simple, burning pleasure of it, his lungs expanding, his heart hammering out a steady beat. He was still an athlete, but his body was no longer just an engine for propulsion; it was an instrument he was learning to tune for a different kind of endurance, the stamina to hold a note, to command a stage, to give a forty-five-minute performance his all. He ran with music in his headphones, not as a distraction, but as a study, dissecting arrangements, internalising rhythms, his mind a constant, buzzing workshop of musical ideas.

The rehearsal space above the pub became their boathouse, their proving ground. It was a cramped, stuffy room that perpetually smelled of the ghosts of spilled beer and forgotten cigarettes, the walls covered in egg cartons that did a questionable job of soundproofing. But within those four walls, a kind of magic began to happen. The initial chaos of four musicians trying to find a common language slowly coalesced into a dynamic, a conversation. Liam, used to the clear, hierarchical structure of a rowing squad, struggled at first with the messy democracy of a band. He found it difficult to articulate the sounds he heard in his head, often falling back on the only vocabulary he had. “It needs more… drive here,” he’d say, gesturing with his hands. “Like the beginning of the stroke, that first big leg push.” Jamie, ever the enthusiastic translator, would grin. “You mean you want the bass and drums to really lean into the downbeat? Hit it hard?” And Chloe, from behind her fortress of cymbals, would unleash a thunderous fill that was exactly the right kind of power, making Liam break into a grateful smile.

They built their setlist piece by piece, an exercise in shared archaeology, digging up classic soul and R&B gems and breathing new life into them. They transformed Wilson Pickett’s ‘In the Midnight Hour’ into a gritty, blues-stomp, and found a swampy, menacing groove in Bill Withers’ ‘Who Is He (And What Is He to You)?’. Steve, the quiet bassist, proved to be their secret weapon, a walking encyclopaedia of music who would suggest a subtle chord change or a different bassline that would unlock an entire song. But their biggest breakthrough came not from a cover, but from a moment of pure, unplanned creation. During a break, while Liam was sipping a bottle of water, Jamie started playing a simple, melancholic guitar riff, a phrase that felt like a question mark hanging in the dusty air. Without thinking, Liam began to hum along, a low, soulful melody taking shape over the chords. The words that emerged were simple, drawn from the landscape of his old life. *“Water like glass, a grey morning sky… another mile to go before the sun gets high…”*

The room fell silent. Jamie’s fingers stilled on the strings. Chloe and Steve looked at him, their expressions a mixture of surprise and intense interest. "What was that, mate?" Jamie asked, his voice soft. Liam felt a hot blush of self-consciousness, the feeling of having been caught in a private moment. "Nothing. Just messing about," he mumbled, turning back to his water. "No," Steve said, his quiet voice cutting through the awkwardness. "That was something. Play the riff again, Jamie." Jamie obliged, and this time, Liam, nudged by their expectant silence, sang the lines again, his voice hesitant at first, then growing in confidence. Chloe joined in with a soft, subtle beat on the ride cymbal, a gentle pulse like a distant train. Steve added a low, looping bassline that gave the melody an anchor. It wasn't a song yet. It was a sketch, a feeling, a fragment of a new story. But it was *his*. For the first time, he wasn't just interpreting someone else's truth; he was beginning to articulate his own. They worked on it for an hour, building a structure, finding a chorus, the music flowing from a place of genuine, collaborative excitement. They called it 'Canal Song'.

The world outside the rehearsal room continued to turn, and one Saturday afternoon, while loading groceries into the boot of Claire’s car, Liam saw a familiar figure jogging towards him. It was Mark, his old rowing partner, his face leaner and more strained than Liam remembered. The encounter was awkward, a meeting of ghosts from different timelines. "Liam! Blimey, didn't recognise you without an oar in your hand," Mark panted, slowing to a stop. "Heard you're a rock star now. How's it going?" The question was friendly, but tinged with a curiosity that felt like a probe. "It's going alright," Liam said, leaning against the car. "We're playing Edale in a few weeks." "Edale, right," Mark nodded, his eyes flicking away. "We're at Henley next weekend. Dave's got us on a brutal schedule. Killing us. We could have used your weight in the eight." The words hung in the air, a casual statement that landed like a small, sharp stone. A pang of guilt, of nostalgia for the simple camaraderie of the crew, hit Liam unexpectedly. "Good luck," Liam said, and was surprised by the sincerity in his own voice. "I hope you win." Mark gave him a strange look, a mixture of gratitude and confusion. "Cheers, mate. You too. Break a leg, or whatever it is you lot say." He jogged off, leaving Liam standing in the supermarket car park, feeling the last, fraying thread connecting him to his old life finally snap.

The final rehearsal before the festival was less a practice and more a declaration of intent. They ran through the entire forty-five-minute set, from the explosive opening of 'Hold On, I'm Comin'' to the quiet, soulful encore of 'Canal Song'. They were no longer four separate musicians; they were a single entity, a tight, powerful unit that breathed and moved as one. They crashed through the final chords of their last song, the sound ringing out in the small, sweaty room, and ended in a sudden, breathless silence. They looked at each other, grinning, exhausted, and united by the shared, electric thrill of creation. They had done the work. They had found their sound. They were a band. "Well," Jamie said, wiping sweat from his brow with the back of his hand. "I reckon we're ready to scare some folk singers." Liam laughed, a deep, easy sound of pure joy. He felt a familiar ache in his muscles and a satisfying rawness in his throat. It was the feeling of having given everything, of having left it all on the floor. He was ready. He was no longer a rower who sang, or a singer who used to row. He was Liam Kenna, and he had a festival to play.The air in the Hope Valley tasted different. It was cleaner, sharper, scented with wild thyme, damp earth, and the distant, enticing aroma of woodsmoke and fried onions. Gone was the familiar, brackish tang of the canal; this was the air of mountains and open spaces, of freedom and possibility. The Edale festival was not just an event; it was a temporary, sprawling city of canvas and colour, pitched in a vast green bowl of a valley and thrumming with a bohemian, life-affirming energy. Colourful flags snapped in the breeze, and the low, rolling thunder of a distant soundcheck mixed with the laughter of children and the gentle cadence of a hundred different conversations. Liam, navigating the crowded, slightly muddy pathways with his bandmates, felt a world away from the manicured lawns and rigid etiquette of a regatta. This was a gathering of tribes, but the uniforms were tie-dye and worn denim, not lycra and club blazers, and the competition was a joyful battle of melodies, not a grim war of attrition against a stopwatch.

They made their way to the main stage, a colossal structure of steel scaffolding and black canvas that seemed to have landed from another planet in the middle of the picturesque valley. It was far bigger than Liam had imagined, a huge, yawning mouth that would soon demand to be filled with sound. Standing at the side of it, looking out at the empty field where thousands of people would soon gather, he felt a familiar, cold spike of fear, a dizzying sense of vertigo. But it was different from the solitary terror of the Voice of the Peaks final. He wasn't alone. Jamie clapped him on the shoulder, a wide, excited grin on his face. “Bit bigger than The Rutland, eh?” Chloe was methodically taping her fingers, her expression one of intense, professional focus, while Steve was quietly tuning his bass, a small, calm smile on his lips. They were a crew, facing their Henley, and the shared sense of purpose was a powerful anchor against the rising tide of his nerves.

Backstage was a controlled, friendly chaos. Roadies in black t-shirts moved with practiced efficiency, coiling cables and checking microphones. Seasoned musicians with faces like road maps and guitars that bore the scars of a thousand gigs nodded a hello as they passed. There was no glitter, no hairspray, just a deep, unspoken respect for the craft. Liam found his family huddled by a catering tent, looking slightly overwhelmed but thrilled. Leo was staring, wide-eyed, at a man with a beard down to his chest who was playing a mandolin. Claire hugged him tightly, her nervous energy a vibrating current. “You okay? You’re not going to be sick, are you?” she whispered fiercely. Liam shook his head, a smile touching his lips. And then he saw his dad, standing slightly apart from the backstage bustle, holding a plastic cup of tea and looking distinctly out of place in his sensible slacks and clean windbreaker. He looked at Liam, then at the huge, empty stage, then back again. He didn’t offer words of encouragement. He just held out a bottle of water he’d been keeping for him. “You’ll be needing this,” was all he said. Liam took it, their hands brushing, the simple, practical gesture a more profound expression of support than any speech could have been.

The forty-five minutes before their set was a blur. They were led to the stage by a cheerful woman with a clipboard. The field was no longer empty; it was a vast, sprawling sea of humanity, a kaleidoscope of picnic blankets, camping chairs, and expectant faces under the bright afternoon sun. This was no darkened auditorium where the audience was an anonymous void. He could see them. He could see their faces, their expressions of curiosity, their smiles. There was nowhere to hide. He took his place at the centre microphone, the stage feeling as wide as a football pitch. He glanced back at Chloe, who gave him a sharp, confident nod. To his left, Steve gave him a thumbs-up. To his right, Jamie grinned, hit a single, loud, defiant chord on his guitar, and the sound exploded from the giant speakers, a declaration that they had arrived. And then Chloe’s drums kicked in, a thunderous, irresistible beat, and they launched into the explosive opening of ‘Hold On, I’m Comin’’.

For the first few moments, Liam was just a passenger, carried along by the sheer power of the band. The sound was immense, a physical force that vibrated through the floorboards of the stage and into the soles of his feet. He opened his mouth and let his voice ride on top of it, a raw, joyful roar that felt like a release of every ounce of pent-up energy and anxiety he possessed. He saw the crowd react, saw their heads turn, saw a ripple of surprise and interest spread through the field. He saw people who had been lying on their blankets sit up, their attention captured. He wasn't just a big man with a surprisingly soulful voice anymore; he was the frontman of a tight, powerful, blues-drenched rock and roll band, and they were a force to be reckoned with. They crashed through the first two songs, a high-octane medley that demanded a physical response, and by the third song, a slinky, groove-laden version of ‘Who Is He (And What Is He to You)?’, a space had opened up at the front of the crowd, and people were dancing, a fluid, joyful mass moving to the rhythm they were creating.

He felt himself relax into it, the performance becoming a conversation, not a test. He moved with the music, feeding off the energy of his bandmates, catching Jamie’s eye and grinning as the guitarist unleashed a blistering solo. He watched Chloe, a blur of motion and concentration, driving the beat forward with a ferocious intensity. He felt Steve’s bassline, a solid, unshakeable foundation that allowed him the freedom to soar. They were a single, living organism, speaking a language of pure, unfiltered emotion. And then, it was time. The high-energy songs faded, and a quiet anticipation settled over the field. Jamie switched to his acoustic guitar, playing the simple, questioning riff they had discovered in the rehearsal room. Liam stepped closer to the microphone, the vast crowd seeming to lean in as one. “This is a new song,” he said, his voice quiet but carrying across the field. “It’s one of ours. It’s about the place I’m from, and the life I used to know. It’s called ‘Canal Song’.”

He sang, and the story of his old life, of the grey dawns and the silent, solitary work, filled the warm summer air of the Hope Valley. The lyrics were a watercolour painting of a world he had left behind, full of images of tearing silk and misty mornings, of aching muscles and the relentless rhythm of the stroke. He sang not with regret, but with a deep, tender understanding, a farewell to the man he had been. The crowd fell utterly silent, a field of thousands holding a collective breath. They weren’t just listening to a song; they were hearing a confession, a testimony, a story of transformation. In the quietest moments of the song, the only sound was his voice, the gentle strum of the guitar, and the whisper of the wind in the festival banners. He was laying his soul bare, not in a theatre under the glare of competitive lights, but in a field, under an open sky, in front of a community of strangers. It was the most honest thing he had ever done.

When the final, gentle chord faded into the afternoon air, the silence held for a beat, a moment of profound, shared resonance. Then, the applause came. It wasn’t the explosive, percussive roar of the TV final. It was a wave, a swell of deep, heartfelt appreciation that grew and grew, washing over the stage. He saw Eleanor Vance at the side of the stage, her arms crossed, a small, profound smile on her face. They finished their set with a triumphant, joyful rendition of ‘Lovely Day’, the entire field singing the chorus back at him, their voices joining his in a huge, harmonious choir. He walked off stage, his legs trembling, his shirt soaked through with sweat, his throat raw, and fell into the waiting, triumphant hugs of his band. They had done it. They had flown.

Later, he stood in the middle of the crowd with his family, just another face in the sea of festival-goers, watching another band on the main stage. The setting sun painted the clouds in shades of pink and orange, the same colours he used to see mirrored on the surface of the canal at dawn. Leo was asleep on his shoulder, a small, warm weight of pure contentment. Claire was leaning against him, her face glowing with happiness. His dad stood beside him, holding a plastic cup of beer, watching the band on stage with a look of quiet concentration. During a break in the music, his dad turned to him. He didn't speak. He just looked at Liam, a long, searching look, and then he raised his plastic cup in a small, almost imperceptible toast. It was a gesture of acknowledgement, of respect, of a quiet, hard-won pride. Liam raised his own bottle of water in return, a silent understanding passing between them. Miles away, in the manicured grounds of Henley-on-Thames, boats were being racked, medals were being awarded, and a life he once thought was his everything was concluding without him. He felt no loss, no regret. He was here, in a field in Derbyshire, surrounded by his family and a new tribe, his ears ringing with music, his heart full. He had found his finish line. It wasn't a line on the water. It was a stage, a song, and a new, wide-open horizon.

The blade sliced the water with a sound like tearing silk, a clean rip in the morning's silence. Liam pulled, his whole body a coiled spring releasing its tension in one fluid, powerful motion. The scull, a fragile needle of carbon fibre, surged forward across the Chesterfield Canal. Dawn was a rumour of pale grey and pink staining the eastern sky, and the air held the raw, damp chill of a Derbyshire spring. Mist clung to the water's surface in lazy drifts, shrouding the banks and turning the distant, iconic twist of the crooked spire into a ghostly smudge on the horizon. Out here, there was only the rhythm. The catch, the drive, the finish, the recovery. The rhythmic gasp of his own breath. The squeak of the oarlocks. For ten years, this had been his sanctuary, his church, his proving ground. The water didn't care about your day job or your family troubles; it only cared about power, technique, and endurance.

But this morning, another rhythm fought for purchase in his mind. A melody. A simple, soulful hook from an old Sam Cooke tune that had snagged in his brain and refused to let go. He found himself humming it on the recovery, a low baritone rumble in his chest that was lost to the wind. The song was a secret, a small, warm thing he carried inside him. Rowing was for his body, for the sinew and muscle he had spent a decade building. Singing was for whatever was left over. It was the part of him that didn't fit the mould of a six-foot-three, fourteen-stone athlete who could pull a two-kilometre erg test in a time that made other men weep. It was a secret garden he tended to in the shower, in his car, and on the rare Tuesday nights he had the courage to go to the open mic at The Rutland Arms.

He let the boat glide, the hiss of the hull on the water slowing as he sat up, wiping a bead of sweat from his brow with the back of his wrist. He pulled his phone from its waterproof pouch. The screen was cold against his thumb. He opened the email again, for what must have been the twentieth time since it had arrived last night. The subject line still gave him a jolt, a fizz of something that felt dangerously like hope.

*Subject: Voice of the Peaks - Grand Final Confirmation*

*Dear Liam Kenna,*
*Following your incredible performance in the semi-final, we are absolutely delighted to invite you to compete in the Grand Final of Voice of the Peaks 2024...*

It was real. The words hadn't rearranged themselves overnight into a rejection. He, Liam Kenna, the quiet lad from Whittington Moor who spent most of his life going backwards down a canal, was in the final of a proper singing competition. Not just a pub karaoke night with a prize of a gallon of ale, but a real, televised-on-a-local-channel, sponsored-by-a-regional-car-dealership competition. The thought was so absurd, so far removed from the cold reality of his aching quads and blistered hands, that he almost laughed out loud. He’d entered on a whim, egged on by his sister, Claire, after she’d filmed him on her phone singing at a family barbecue. He’d sent in the grainy video of him murdering—or so he thought—Otis Redding’s ‘(Sittin' On) The Dock of the Bay’, and somehow, against all odds, they’d invited him to an audition.

The early rounds had been a blur of nervous energy. He’d stood backstage in his borrowed suit, feeling like a bear in a doll's house amongst the slender, confident drama school kids and the seasoned pub singers with their worn-out guitars. Then he’d walked on stage, the lights hot on his face, and opened his mouth. And the voice that came out always surprised him. It was deeper, richer, than his speaking voice, a resonant sound that seemed to come from the soles of his feet. It felt like the only time he was ever truly expressing the entirety of himself. The judges, a panel of local radio DJs and a former West End performer who’d retired to the Peak District, had been visibly taken aback. ‘Where did *that* voice come from, young man?’ one of them had asked, peering at him over her glasses as if he were some sort of geological anomaly.

"He's here. The phantom of the canal."

Liam jolted, nearly dropping his phone in the water. Dave, his coach, was standing on the towpath, arms crossed over his chest, his stocky frame silhouetted against the brightening sky. His face, weathered and perpetually unimpressed, was fixed on Liam.

"Daydreaming, Kenna? Or admiring your reflection?" Dave's voice was gravelly, a product of too many years of shouting encouragement through a megaphone into the wind.

"Just checking the time, coach," Liam lied, quickly stowing the phone. He grabbed the oars, his knuckles white.

"The time is 'time to put some bloody work in'," Dave grunted. "Your splits for that last five hundred were lazy. Your head's not in the boat. The Northern Regatta is in three weeks. Manchester will eat you alive if you're pulling like that. I want three sets of five-hundred-metre sprints. And I want to see the water churn."

Liam nodded, his jaw tight. "Yes, coach."

He didn't argue. You didn't argue with Dave. The man had coached rowers to national championships. He lived and breathed the sport, and he expected the same monastic devotion from his top athletes. He would not, Liam knew, understand a singing competition. To Dave, anything that wasn't geared towards making the boat go faster was a frivolous, pointless distraction. A weakness.

As he turned the scull and paddled back to his starting point, the conflict churned inside him, a messy counter-rhythm to the smooth mechanics of the stroke. Rowing was his life, the bedrock of his identity. It had given him discipline, strength, a community. He owed everything to it, and to Dave. But the singing… the singing was a new, thrilling discovery. It was a door opening into a room in his own house that he never knew existed. The Grand Final was in Sheffield, at the City Hall, in two weeks’ time. Two weeks. He had to choose a song, practice, figure out what to wear. He had to drive there. His car, a battered fifteen-year-old Ford Fiesta he’d nicknamed ‘The Biscuit Tin’ for its tendency to rattle, would have to be coaxed into making the journey over the moors.

He took a deep breath, the cold air burning his lungs. For now, he would row. He would make the water churn for Dave. He would give the canal the power it demanded. But as he coiled his body for the first sprint, it wasn't the thought of the finish line at the regatta that spurred him on. It was the memory of the stage lights, the hush of the crowd, and the first, terrifying, wonderful note of a song taking flight.

The boathouse smelled of damp lycra, river water, and industrial floor cleaner. It was a familiar, comforting smell to Liam, the scent of hard work and belonging. He racked his boat with the practiced ease of long habit, his muscles humming with the pleasant ache of exertion. Other members of the club were arriving now, a trickle of bodies in brightly coloured technical gear, their voices echoing in the cavernous space.

"Morning, Liam. Good session?" It was Mark, another single sculler, a wiry accountant who rowed with a ferocious intensity that belied his day job.

"Morning. Yeah, not bad," Liam replied, towelling his hair dry. "Dave was on the warpath, as usual."

Mark chuckled. "Tells you he cares. When he stops shouting, that’s when you need to worry." He paused, lowering his voice slightly. "Heard a rumour on the club WhatsApp. Something about you being on the telly?"

Liam felt a hot blush creep up his neck. He’d hoped to keep it quiet for a bit longer, to let the idea settle in his own mind before it became club gossip. But news, like water, always found a way to leak out. "Ah. Yeah. Sort of. Local telly, maybe."

Mark's eyes widened. "Don't be modest, mate! The Voice of the Peaks! My missus loves that show. She said there was a big lad from Chesterfield who sang like an angel. Didn't realise it was you! That's brilliant! What are you gonna sing in the final?"

The question hung in the air. Liam hadn't even let himself think that far ahead. The pressure of it suddenly felt immense. "Not sure yet. Got to pick something."

"Well, whatever it is, you'll smash it," Mark said, clapping him on the shoulder with a wet hand. "Just don't forget us little people when you're famous."

The encounter left Liam feeling strangely exposed. The two halves of his life, the rower and the singer, were beginning to collide, and he wasn't sure how to manage the impact. He finished changing in a haze, nodding and murmuring vague pleasantries to his clubmates, all the while feeling their curious glances. He was no longer just Liam Kenna, the club's strongest sculler. He was a novelty. The Singing Rower.

He escaped the boathouse and got into The Biscuit Tin. The engine turned over with a phlegmy cough and a shudder that vibrated through the driver’s seat. The dashboard lit up like a Christmas tree with warning lights that he’d long since learned to ignore. As long as the oil light and the engine temperature light stayed off, he considered it a victory. He pulled out of the car park, the radio crackling to life. A generic pop song filled the small car. He turned it off. He needed to think.

Driving through the familiar streets of Chesterfield, past the market stalls being set up and the morning commuters heading to the train station, he felt a disconnect. This was his world. Solid, predictable, real. The singing competition felt like a dream he was having, and he was terrified of waking up. What if he made a fool of himself? What if he got on that big stage and his voice cracked? What if the judges who had been so kind before were suddenly critical? The fear was a cold knot in his stomach, a stark contrast to the elation he'd felt just a few hours earlier. Rowing had taught him to manage physical pain and exhaustion, but this... this was different. This was a fear of failure that was purely about his soul.

He pulled up outside his small terraced house. His sister’s car was parked outside. Claire must have dropped off her son, Leo, for him to look after while she was at work. Liam smiled. Leo, his seven-year-old nephew, would be a welcome distraction. The boy lived entirely in the moment, his world a whirlwind of Lego, football, and endless questions.

He opened the front door to the immediate assault of a small, human hurricane.

"Uncle Liam! You promised we could go to the park! And you said you'd show me your medals again! Did you win today? Did you beat everyone? Mum said you're going to be a pop star!"

Leo was already dressed in a full, slightly-too-large football kit, and was bouncing on the balls of his feet with an energy Liam envied. Claire was in the kitchen, making toast. She was two years older than Liam, a primary school teacher with a practical, no-nonsense attitude, but with the same kind eyes as their late mother.

"Morning, superstar," she said, grinning at him. "Surviving the hype?"

Liam grunted, ruffling Leo’s hair. "Barely. Mark at the club already knows. I feel like a prize pig at a country fair."

"Get used to it," Claire said, handing him a mug of tea. "I put it on the school's parent Facebook group. The whole of Brampton is rooting for you."

"You what?" Liam choked on his tea. "Claire! Why would you do that?"

"Because I'm proud of you, you big idiot!" she retorted, her expression softening. "For years, all you've done is that bloody rowing. Up at five every morning, protein shakes, blisters, aches and pains. You never do anything just for fun. This is for fun. And you're brilliant at it. You need to let yourself enjoy it."

"It's not just for fun anymore, is it?" Liam said, his voice quiet. "It's the final. There's a prize. People are... watching."

Claire came and put an arm around his broad shoulders. "Listen to me. You've been singing since you were Leo's age. Mum used to say you sang before you could talk properly. You used to stand on that hearth, remember? Using the TV remote as a microphone, singing along to her Dusty Springfield records. Her heart would have burst seeing you on that stage."

The mention of their mum struck a chord deep inside him. She had been the music in their house. After she’d passed away from cancer five years ago, the house had fallen silent in more ways than one. His dad, a man of few words at the best of times, had retreated further into himself. For Liam, singing the old songs they’d shared had become a way of keeping her close, a private conversation with her memory. Maybe that’s what this was all about.

"Just… don't let Dave from the rowing club find out," Liam mumbled into his mug.

Claire laughed, a bright, clear sound. "Oh, he'll be fine. Might do him good to realise there's more to life than messing about in boats. Now," she said, turning her attention to her son, "Leo, be good for your uncle. No breaking anything expensive. And Liam," she fixed him with a mock-serious glare, "you need to pick a song for the final. A proper showstopper. No sad ballads. Something that'll get them on their feet."

As she left for work, leaving a trail of perfume and cheerful chaos in her wake, Liam was left alone with his nephew and his thoughts. A showstopper. The words echoed in his head. He looked around the small living room, at the mantelpiece crowded with rowing trophies and a single, faded photograph of his smiling mother. He had two weeks to become a showman. Two weeks to bridge the chasm between the silent, powerful man in the boat and the soulful singer he was only just beginning to know. The prospect was, in a word, terrifying. And in another, completely and utterly exhilarating.

The silence that followed Claire's departure was immediately filled by Leo, who began using the living room rug as a makeshift football pitch, commentating on his own imaginary game in a breathless whisper. "And Kenna shoots... he scores! The crowd goes wild!" Liam watched him, a faint smile on his lips. He sank into the worn armchair, the springs groaning in protest under his weight. His body felt heavy, anchored by fatigue, but his mind was a frantic buzz of conflicting demands. The regatta. The final. Dave's gravelly voice. Claire's cheerful encouragement. His mother’s smile. It was too much.

"Can we see the medals now?" Leo abandoned his game, skidding to a halt by the arm of the chair and looking up at him with wide, pleading eyes. "Please? The shiny ones."

"Alright, alright, you little monster," Liam sighed, heaving himself up. It was a familiar ritual. He opened the glass-fronted cabinet where his prizes were kept. Dozens of them, mostly gold and silver, hung from ribbons or stood on small wooden plinths. He took down the heaviest, a gold medal from the National Championships two years prior. "This one's from when we won the coxless fours," he explained, placing the cool, heavy metal in Leo’s small hands. The boy’s eyes were round with awe. "It was the hardest race I've ever done. It was raining so hard you could barely see the finish line, and my hands were so raw I could feel the oar through the blisters." He spoke of the race with a detached reverence, as if describing a natural disaster he had survived. This, he understood. The pain, the burn, the reward. It was a simple, brutal equation.

Leo traced the embossed crest on the medal. "Is being a pop star harder than this?" he asked, his voice full of genuine curiosity. Liam was taken aback. He looked from the medal in Leo’s hand—a tangible record of a decade of gruelling, single-minded effort—to the memory of the stage, a fleeting, terrifying, thirty-minute blur.

"I don't know, mate," he said honestly. "It's… different." He put the medal away, the click of the cabinet door sounding unnervingly final. "In a race, you know what you've got to do. You pull as hard as you can. If you're strong enough and your technique's good enough, you win. On stage… you can do everything right and people still might not like it. It’s not about how strong you are."

"But they do like it! Mum said you made Mrs. Higgins from next door cry, but in a good way," Leo insisted. "What song are you going to sing? Is it the one about the boat?" He meant '(Sittin' On) The Dock of the Bay'. Liam shook his head. "No, Claire's right. It needs to be something… bigger. A showstopper." The word felt foreign and ridiculous in his mouth. He wasn't a showman; he was a sculler. He moved backwards to go forwards. He faced away from where he was going. His entire sporting life was an exercise in quiet, introverted propulsion.

He sat back down and scrolled through his phone's music library, a curated collection of soul, blues, and old-school R&B that was a world away from the aggressive punk and rock that fuelled his teammates' workouts. He needed something that had power but also vulnerability. Something that could build, that could tell a story. He skimmed past Al Green, past Bill Withers. Then his thumb hovered over an album cover. Otis Redding again. But not the gentle melancholy of 'Dock of the Bay'. He tapped on 'Try a Little Tenderness'.

The song started soft and gentle, a simple declaration. Liam closed his eyes, listening. He knew every inflection, every breath. Then came the build. The horns kicking in, the tempo increasing, Redding’s voice cracking with raw, pleading emotion, building and building until it became a volcanic eruption of pure soul. It wasn't just a song; it was a three-and-a-half-minute emotional storm. It was technically demanding, vocally athletic, and utterly exposing. It was, he realised with a jolt of fear and excitement, a showstopper. It was perfect.

"Oh, young woman, they're so sweet..." he sang quietly, just under his breath, his deep voice barely a murmur. Leo's head popped up. "Sing it louder!" he demanded. Liam glanced at the closed curtains, a habitual secrecy taking over. But then he looked at his nephew’s expectant face, and at the photo of his mother on the mantelpiece, and something inside him loosened. He took a breath and sang the line again, this time letting his voice fill the small room. It felt good. It felt right. By the time he reached the explosive final section, he was on his feet, using a rolled-up magazine as a microphone, belting out the "Got to, got to, got to!" part with a passion that made Leo whoop with delight and start dancing around the coffee table. For a moment, he wasn't Liam the Rower or Liam the Finalist. He was just a man singing in his living room, his heart full, sharing a moment of pure, unadulterated joy with the small boy who idolised him. The music faded, leaving him breathless, his chest heaving, a wide grin spreading across his face. This was what Claire meant. This was for fun. This was for him. This was for her.

The euphoria of the living room performance evaporated in the harsh fluorescent light of the club’s gym. The next few days fell into a brutal, familiar pattern. Pre-dawn sessions on the water, followed by punishing workouts on the rowing machines in the evening. The ergometer became his penitent's stool. He would strap his feet in, set the monitor for a two-thousand-metre piece, and pull. The fan whirred like a jet engine, the chain rattled, and the digital numbers on the screen became his entire world: split time, stroke rate, power output. But now, the machine had a soundtrack. The slow, soulful intro of ‘Try a Little Tenderness’ timed itself perfectly to his warm-up strokes. The explosive, desperate pleading of the song’s climax became the internal roar that accompanied his final sprint, his legs burning with lactic acid, his vision tunnelling.

Dave watched him like a hawk. The coach would stand with his arms crossed, his gaze flicking between Liam's strained face and the unforgiving numbers on the monitor. He didn’t say much, which was more unnerving than his usual bellowing. He’d just circle the machine, his presence a heavy weight, occasionally tapping the screen. “Power’s fluctuating, Kenna. Your drive is inconsistent. One stroke you’re a god, the next you’re a tourist on a pedalo. Where’s your head at?” Liam, gasping for air, his throat raw, could only shake his head and try to focus. But focusing meant choosing one rhythm over the other, and his mind refused to cooperate. The rower and the singer were at war, and his body was the battlefield.

After one particularly gruelling session, where his final five-hundred-metre split was two seconds slower than his personal best, Dave followed him to the water fountain. "Alright, Liam. Out with it." The coach’s voice was low, devoid of its usual bluster. It was the voice he used for serious conversations, the one that could cut through any excuse. "Something's off. You're strong, you're fit, but you're not here." He tapped his own temple. "You're somewhere else. Family okay? Work?"

Liam let the cold water run over his hands, stalling. This was the moment. The moment to tell him, to explain the absurd, wonderful, terrifying thing that had happened. But the words wouldn't form. He pictured Dave's face, the inevitable dismissal, the disappointment. To Dave, this would be a betrayal of everything they had worked for. It would be a weakness. "Just tired, coach," he mumbled, not meeting his eye. "Not sleeping well."

Dave let out a long, slow breath, a sigh of profound frustration. "Well, you'd better get it sorted. The regatta is everything we've aimed for this season. To make sure you’re ready, I've booked the senior squad into a full immersion training camp at Holme Pierrepont. Starts Friday next week. We drive down after work. Two solid days. No phones, no family, no distractions. Just us, the water, and the work. I need your head completely in the boat, son. Completely."

The words hit Liam like a physical blow. Friday next week. The Grand Final was on the Saturday. In Sheffield. Holme Pierrepont was in Nottingham, a good hour's drive away in the wrong direction. The carefully constructed wall separating his two lives had just been demolished by a wrecking ball. He felt a wave of nausea. He just nodded dumbly, the lie he’d told moments before trapping him. "Yeah. Okay, coach. Sounds good."

The drive home in The Biscuit Tin was a journey through a fog of panic. The conflict was no longer a philosophical one; it was a logistical nightmare. He couldn't be in two places at once. He couldn't serve two masters, especially not when one was as demanding as Dave and the other was as seductive as a sold-out auditorium. He parked on a quiet lane overlooking the town, the crooked spire just visible through the dusk, and killed the engine. He pulled out his phone and played the Otis Redding track. He tried to sing along, to find that soaring power he’d discovered in his living room. But his throat was tight, constricted by anxiety. The notes that had flown so freely were now caged in his chest, weak and breathless. He wasn't a showstopper. He was a fraud who was about to let everyone down.

He didn't go home. Instead, he drove straight to Claire's house on the other side of town. He found her in the garden, patiently trying to untangle a set of solar-powered fairy lights while Leo directed her from a small plastic chair. She took one look at his face and set the tangled mess down. "Oh dear," she said. "That's your 'world-is-ending' face. I haven't seen that since you accidentally snapped one of Dave's precious carbon-fibre oars."

In a torrent of words, he explained the situation. The training camp. Dave’s ultimatum. The impossibility of it all. "I have to choose," he finished, slumping onto the garden bench. "And I don't know how. If I miss the camp, I'm letting the whole squad down. Dave will probably kick me out of the first boat. My season will be over. But if I don't go to the final..." He trailed off, unable to voice the alternative. To give up on the singing felt like cutting out a part of himself.

Claire listened, her brow furrowed in concentration. She picked up a stray football and bounced it on her knee, a habit she had when she was thinking hard. "Right," she said finally, her tone shifting from sympathetic sister to military strategist. "This isn't a choice. It's a scheduling problem. We're not choosing, we're managing." She started pacing on the small patch of lawn. "You go to the camp on Friday. You do the sessions. You tell Dave you have a… a family commitment you can’t get out of on Saturday evening. A christening. A cousin's wedding. Something boring he can't argue with."

"He'll know I'm lying," Liam groaned. "He can smell a lie from the other side of the canal."

"He won't care, as long as you're there for the important sessions," she countered, waving a dismissive hand. "So, you do the Saturday morning session. You give it everything you've got. Then you get in your car at, say, two o'clock. You drive to Sheffield. You check into a cheap hotel I'll find for you. You have a shower, you put on the new suit we are going to buy you, and you go to the City Hall. You walk on that stage, you sing your heart out, and you win the whole damn thing. Then," she took a deep breath, "you get back in your car, you drive back to Nottingham, get three hours sleep, and you're back on the water for the Sunday morning time trial. Simple."

Liam stared at her as if she had just suggested he row to the moon. The plan was ludicrous, a punishing marathon of driving, stress, and sleep deprivation that would leave him wrecked for both events. It was a recipe for spectacular, public failure on two separate fronts. "Claire, that's insane. I'll be exhausted. My voice will be shot. I won't be able to row the next day. I'll crash the car. I'll… I'll fail at both."

She stopped pacing and came to stand in front of him, her expression fierce with a belief he couldn't begin to muster for himself. "Liam Kenna, since when have you ever backed down from something because it was hard? You get up at five in the morning to train in the freezing rain. You've rowed until your hands bled.
