You push your body to its absolute limit every single day for a piece of metal on a ribbon. This is just another race. It's longer, and a bit more complicated, but it's the same thing. You just have to grit your teeth and pull."

Claire’s words hung in the evening air, a blueprint for a miracle or a disaster. Liam stared at her, his mind reeling. The sheer audacity of the plan was breathtaking. It was a house of cards built on a lie, a punishing physical ordeal, and the reliability of a fifteen-year-old Ford Fiesta. Every rational instinct, every ounce of the disciplined caution that rowing had beaten into him, screamed that it was impossible. He would be spreading himself too thin, guaranteeing failure on all fronts. He would be a subpar rower and a hoarse, exhausted singer.

"It won't work," he said, the words heavy with defeat. "My body won't take it. The drive, the lack of sleep... I'll be useless for the time trial on Sunday. Dave will see right through it." He imagined his coach's disappointed, flinty gaze as he posted a sluggish time, the quiet 'I told you so' that would follow. The thought made his stomach clench. "And the singing… how can I sing a song like that, a song that needs everything you've got, when I'm running on empty?"

Claire stopped her pacing and took the football from Leo, who had been watching their exchange with the solemn intensity of a referee. She tucked it under her arm. "You're thinking like a rower, Liam. You're looking at the splits, the timings, the energy expenditure. You're not factoring in the one thing that rowing doesn't measure." She tapped her chest. "Heart. Adrenaline. The buzz you'll get from walking on that stage. That will carry you. That will be your fuel. Remember when Mum used to say you had more grit than sense? This is one of those times. You just have to decide if you have the guts to try."

She was right. He did think in numbers and physical limits. Rowing was a science of pain management and power curves. But singing… singing was alchemy. It was turning breath and memory into something that could make a stranger feel an emotion. He looked at his sister's determined face, so like their mother's in that moment, and felt a flicker of her insane optimism. What was the alternative? To call the competition organisers and withdraw? To tell them the quiet lad from Whittington Moor with the surprisingly big voice had to go to a training camp instead? The thought was unbearable. It felt like turning his back on that secret garden he’d tended for so long, letting all the flowers wither.

"A christening?" he asked, his voice barely a whisper. The lie felt sticky and unpleasant in his mouth.

Claire’s face broke into a triumphant grin. "Exactly. Your second cousin, once removed. On your dad's side. Incredibly devout family. Utterly unmissable. Dave won’t know any different. Now, first things first, we're going suit shopping tomorrow. You can't sing a showstopper looking like you're about to unblock a drain."

The following Saturday, Liam found himself standing awkwardly in the men's department of a Debenhams in Sheffield, feeling like an overgrown bear that had wandered into a haberdashery. The world of slim-fit trousers and tailored jackets was utterly alien to him. His wardrobe consisted of technical sportswear, work jeans, and a handful of check shirts. Claire, however, was in her element, pulling jackets from rails with ruthless efficiency. "No, not double-breasted, it'll make you look like a wardrobe," she muttered, discarding one option. "That one's too shiny, you'll look like a cruise ship entertainer." She finally thrust a dark charcoal suit at him. "Try this."

He retreated to the changing room, the space feeling laughably small. He wrestled his way into the crisp shirt and trousers, his broad shoulders and thick thighs straining against the unfamiliar fabric. When he finally put on the jacket and looked in the mirror, he barely recognised the man staring back. The suit was well-cut, slimming his frame and giving him a silhouette that was less 'brute force' and more ' quiet authority'. The charcoal fabric complimented his dark hair and the deep blue of the shirt Claire had chosen brought out the colour of his eyes. For the first time, he saw a glimmer of the man who could walk onto the stage at the City Hall. He wasn't just Liam the rower in borrowed clothes; he was someone else. A performer. The idea sent a nervous thrill right through him. He stepped out. Claire’s hand flew to her mouth. "Oh, Liam," she breathed. "You look... incredible. Mum would have loved this." The simple, heartfelt words were the only validation he needed.

The lie was the hardest part. He cornered Dave on Tuesday, after a brutal session on the water where he’d pushed himself to the point of seeing stars, determined to prove his commitment before he confessed his fictional family obligation. The coach was wiping down a boat, his movements methodical. Liam cleared his throat. "Coach, can I have a word?" Dave grunted an affirmative, not looking up. "It’s about the training camp. On Saturday," Liam began, his heart thumping against his ribs. "I’ve got a family thing I can’t get out of. A christening. In the evening. I can do the morning sessions, no problem, but I’ll have to leave in the afternoon."

Dave stopped wiping. He slowly straightened up and turned to face Liam, his eyes narrowed. He was silent for a long, agonising moment, his expression unreadable. "A christening," he repeated, the words flat. It wasn't a question. Liam nodded, his mouth dry. He braced himself for the explosion, the accusations, the dismissal. But it didn't come. Dave just looked at him, a flicker of something—disappointment, maybe even hurt—in his gaze. "Your attendance at family events has never been a problem before, Kenna." He picked up a rag and tossed it into a bucket with a wet slap. "Fine. Be there for the morning. I want two faultless sessions out of you. And you be back on that water at seven a.m. Sunday for the time trial. And you had better not be tired. Your cousin’s soul might be saved on Saturday, but your place in this boat won’t be if you pull a lazy time. Am I clear?"

"Crystal, coach," Liam said, the relief so profound it almost buckled his knees. He had his permission, conditional though it was. But Dave’s final look, a long, searching stare, left him feeling cold. The coach knew something was up. He just didn’t know what. The lie now felt less like a clever piece of scheduling and more like a debt that would be called in at 7 a.m. on Sunday morning.

The rest of the week was a frantic, secret balancing act. On the water, he was a machine, his focus absolute, trying to placate Dave and banish any lingering suspicion. His splits improved. The water churned. But every spare moment was consumed by Otis Redding. He’d take The Biscuit Tin to the furthest corner of the supermarket car park on his lunch break, windows rolled up, and sing. He’d start soft, feeling the melody in his chest, and then build, letting his voice fill the small, rattling car, pushing for that raw, desperate edge in the song's climax. He sang to the steering wheel, the faded air freshener, the cracked dashboard. He sang until his throat ached, then he’d chew a throat lozenge and drive back to work, the secret rumble of the song still vibrating inside him. The two halves of his life were running in parallel, a hair's breadth from a catastrophic collision.

Friday arrived with a heavy, grey sky that threatened rain. Liam packed his car, the dissonance of his luggage a perfect metaphor for his state of mind. On one side of the boot was his long rowing bag, containing his lycra, his waterproof gear, and the familiar scent of river water and effort. On the other, hanging in a pristine garment bag, was the charcoal suit. It looked impossibly sophisticated and completely out of place, a visitor from another life. Claire and Leo came out to see him off. Leo gave his leg a fierce hug. "Break a leg, Uncle Liam!" he shouted, slightly misquoting his mother's instructions.

Claire handed him a travel mug and a bag of sandwiches. Her usual cheerful bravado was gone, replaced by a quiet intensity. "Drive carefully. Don't think about Sunday morning, don't think about Dave. When you get to Sheffield, just think about the song. Nothing else. You can do this," she said, squeezing his arm. He got into The Biscuit Tin, the engine catching on the third try with a worrying cough. As he pulled away from the curb, he saw Claire and Leo in his rearview mirror, waving, a tiny island of unwavering belief. He turned the corner and they were gone. He was alone, on the road to Nottingham, to the first leg of his impossible, terrifying, exhilarating double life. The plan was in motion. There was no turning back now.

The Holme Pierrepont National Water Sports Centre was a place stripped of all sentiment. It was a factory for speed, all concrete, glass, and vast, intimidating stretches of flat water, engineered for perfect racing conditions. As Liam pulled The Biscuit Tin into the car park alongside the sleek Audis and BMWs of his teammates, he felt a profound sense of alienation. The other rowers were already unloading their gear, their voices loud and confident, their conversation a familiar litany of split times, rigging adjustments, and gossip about the rival Manchester club. They were a tribe gathering for war, and Liam, with his charcoal suit hanging in the back of his car like a guilty secret, felt like a spy in their midst. He was physically present, his body going through the well-rehearsed motions of unpacking and preparing his scull, but his mind was miles away, in a different city, humming a different tune.

The Friday evening session was brutal. The sun had long set, and the course was lit by harsh floodlights that turned the water into a black, reflective oil slick. The air was cold and bitingly damp. Dave herded them through a series of relentless power drills, his voice, distorted by the megaphone, echoing across the darkness. "Drive! Legs! Kenna, your finish is sloppy! Are you tired already?" For two hours, Liam rowed on instinct. He let the animal part of his brain take over, the part that knew only the burn in the quads, the strain in the back, the raw, scraping gasp for air. He tried to empty his head, to make it a blank space filled only with Dave's commands and the rhythm of the boat. But the melody of 'Try a Little Tenderness' was persistent. It weaved itself between the squeak of the oarlocks and the splash of the oars, a quiet, soulful counterpoint to the violent exertion of his body. He felt split in two, a ghost in his own machine.

On Saturday morning, the atmosphere in the spartan canteen was thick with tension. Liam sat with the senior squad, methodically eating a bowl of porridge he couldn't taste. The christening lie felt flimsy and absurd in the bright morning light. Mark, the wiry accountant, sat opposite him, wolfing down toast. "Big day for the Kenna clan, eh? Don't let the holy water make you soft for the time trial tomorrow." The others chuckled. Liam forced a tight smile, feeling the heat rise in his cheeks. He caught Dave’s eye from across the room. The coach was watching him, his expression cold and appraising, as if trying to solve a complex equation. There was no sympathy there, only a demand. Liam knew he had to deliver on the water. It was the only currency Dave respected, the only way to pay for the lie he was about to tell.

His first session was in the single scull, his sanctuary and his proving ground. As he pushed off from the pontoon, he felt a grim sense of determination settle over him. This was a test. He paddled to the 2000-metre start line, the water calm and glassy. Dave stood on the bank, stopwatch in hand. This was it. Liam took a deep breath, coiled his body, and on Dave’s sharp command, he exploded into motion. He channelled everything into the oars: the anxiety, the guilt, the fear of failure, the impossible hope for the evening ahead. He turned it all into raw, blistering power. He didn't think, he just pulled. He focused on the pain, embracing it, using it. When he finally collapsed over the finish line, his lungs screaming and his vision blurred with black spots, he knew he had left nothing in the tank. He drifted for a minute, recovering his breath, before glancing at the bank. Dave looked at his stopwatch, then back at Liam. He gave a single, sharp nod. It was the highest praise Liam could have hoped for.

The second session, in the coxless four, was a greater challenge. It was about unity, a seamless blend of four bodies and minds. His crewmates were the club’s best, and they tolerated no weakness. For the first few hundred metres, Liam struggled, his timing a fraction off, his mind still reeling from the solo effort. He felt a jarring bump through the hull, a sign of his blade clashing with another's rhythm. "Get it together, Liam!" hissed the rower in front of him. The rebuke shocked him back to the present. He shut his eyes for a single stroke, found the shared beat, the pulsing heart of the boat, and locked in. The jarring vanished, replaced by a smooth, powerful surge. They became one entity, the eight oars dipping and pulling in perfect, silent synchronicity. They flew across the water, the boat feeling light and alive beneath them. It was the magic of rowing, the feeling he had chased for ten years, and for a few glorious minutes, it eclipsed everything else.

Getting away was the most awkward part. He showered and changed quickly, his heart hammering with a new kind of nervous energy. He packed his kit, acutely aware of Dave’s presence lingering by the boathouse door. "You’ll send our love to the little one, won't you, Liam?" Mark called out with a grin. Liam just nodded, his throat too tight to speak. He loaded his bag into The Biscuit Tin, trying to act casual, as if he were just popping out for a few hours. Dave walked over, wiping his hands on a rag. He didn't mention the christening. "Seven a.m.," he said, his voice low and gravelly. "That time trial is for your seat in the boat at the regatta. Nothing else matters. Don't be late." The unspoken part of the sentence hung heavily between them: *And you had better be in a fit state to race.* Liam met his coach's hard gaze. "I won't be, coach." He got in the car, turned the key, and held his breath. The engine sputtered, coughed, then finally rattled into life. He didn't look back as he drove out of the car park and onto the main road, leaving the world of water and work behind him.

The ninety-minute drive to Sheffield was a journey between planets. The Biscuit Tin rattled along the M1, its protests a worrying soundtrack to Liam’s escalating panic. The relief of escaping the camp was quickly replaced by the terrifying reality of what lay ahead. He was driving towards the biggest performance of his life, fuelled by porridge and a lie, with the threat of a career-defining time trial hanging over him the next morning. He tried to do some vocal warm-ups, humming scales, but his voice was tight and his throat felt dry. He was a rower who had just completed two gruelling, race-pace sessions. He wasn't a singer preparing for a final. He was an athlete, and his body was crying out for rest, for protein, for an ice bath, not for a three-and-a-half-minute emotional storm on a public stage. Doubt, cold and insidious, began to creep in. Claire's plan, which had seemed so brilliantly defiant in her back garden, now felt like a fool's errand, a script for a tragedy in two acts.

He found the budget hotel Claire had booked on the outskirts of Sheffield city centre. It was a drab, functional building wedged between a tyre depot and a fast-food restaurant. The room was small and aggressively beige, with a window that overlooked a car park. The air smelled faintly of stale smoke and bleach. It was the most beautiful, most welcome place he had ever seen. The anonymity was a blessing. Here, he wasn't Kenna the rower or Kenna the finalist. He was just a man in a beige room with a suit in a bag. He had two hours until he needed to be at the City Hall. He stood under the shower for a long time, the hot water beating down on his aching shoulders, trying to wash away the scent of the river and the lingering tension of the morning. He was trying to wash the rower off and let the singer emerge.

He dried himself off and walked over to the bed where he had carefully laid out the suit. It looked impossibly dark and formal against the cheap, patterned bedspread. Slowly, methodically, as if it were a pre-race ritual, he began to dress. The crisp, clean shirt. The perfectly knotted tie. The smart trousers. Finally, he shrugged on the charcoal jacket. He turned to face the full-length mirror screwed to the back of the door. The man who stared back was a stranger. The familiar, bulky frame was still there, but the suit gave it a different shape, a different meaning. His face was pale with exhaustion and nerves, but his eyes were bright, wide with a terrifying, electric anticipation. He was no longer the phantom of the canal or Dave's errant athlete. He was Liam Kenna, finalist. He took a deep, shuddering breath. The plan, Claire's insane, impossible plan, had worked. He was here. Now, all that was left to do was walk into the light and sing.

The short walk from the hotel to the Sheffield City Hall was a journey through a dreamscape. Liam moved through the Saturday evening crowds, a ghost in a sharp suit. The city was alive with the thrum of weekend nightlife; music spilled from pub doorways, and the air smelled of perfume and exhaust fumes. He felt utterly detached from it all, a bubble of quiet panic moving through the boisterous streets. His body was a catalogue of aches: his shoulders, his back, his legs, all screaming in protest from the morning’s exertions. He felt hollowed out, a vessel scoured clean by effort and anxiety, and he couldn't imagine how he was going to fill it with a voice big enough to reach the back of the auditorium. Then he saw it. The City Hall was grander and more imposing than he had imagined, its stone façade floodlit against the bruised twilight sky. Banners for 'Voice of the Peaks' hung between the columns. A small crowd had gathered near the entrance, held back by barriers, their phone screens held aloft. It was real. This wasn't a pub open mic; it was an event. The absurdity of his presence here, the sheer, improbable leap from a Chesterfield canal to this grand stage, hit him with the force of a physical shock. He felt a desperate urge to turn around, to get back into The Biscuit Tin and drive, not back to the rowing camp, but just away, anywhere.

Backstage was a different kind of chaos from the focused tension of a regatta. It was a dizzying world of glitter, hairspray, and theatrical anxiety. Slender young women in shimmering dresses practiced vocal scales in corners, while men with carefully styled hair and worn-out guitars paced nervously, muttering lyrics to themselves. The air buzzed with a competitive energy that was both sharper and more fragile than the brute-force rivalry he knew. In the rowing world, you could see your competition’s strength in their physique, in the numbers on the ergometer. Here, the weapons were hidden, carried in the larynx and the heart, and the uncertainty was terrifying. Liam felt like a Shire horse at a greyhound race, too big, too solid, his movements too economical for this frantic, glittering space. He found an unoccupied corner behind a stack of flight cases, the cool wall a welcome anchor against the dizzying swirl of it all. He was Liam Kenna, the Singing Rower. A novelty act. A geological anomaly. The judges’ words came back to him, and for the first time, they felt less like a compliment and more like a label for a freak.

He pulled out his phone, his thumb clumsy on the screen. There was a text from Claire. *'Just sing it for Mum. She's in the front row of your heart. Smash it. Love you. P.S. Leo says you're better than Harry Styles.'* A small, involuntary smile touched his lips. He read the message again, the words a lifeline. *Sing it for Mum.* It cut through the noise, the fear, the impostor syndrome. It gave him a purpose beyond winning, beyond the judges, beyond the television cameras. This wasn't about them. It was about that secret garden, that part of him he’d shared only with her memory. It was about standing on the hearth with a TV remote for a microphone. He closed his eyes, picturing her smiling face, and the tight knot of panic in his chest loosened just a fraction. He felt a hand on his arm and jolted. A harried-looking woman with a headset and a clipboard was looking at him. "Liam Kenna? You're on after this act. Five minutes."

The walk from the wings felt like the longest journey of his life. The previous contestant, a young girl with a powerful pop voice, was taking her bow to rapturous applause. The sound washed over him, a physical wave of noise. Then the stage manager gave him a gentle push, and he was walking out into the light. It was blinding, a wall of pure heat and brightness that erased the audience, turning the vast auditorium into a deep, unknowable darkness punctuated by the faint red glow of recording lights. He could just make out the judges' table, a long, dark shape where the three arbiters of his fate sat in silhouette. He found his mark in the centre of the stage, a simple piece of tape on the floor that felt like the loneliest spot on earth. The applause for the previous singer died away, replaced by an expectant, cavernous silence. In that silence, his exhaustion roared back. A profound, bone-deep weariness. He could feel the two sessions from that morning in every screaming muscle fibre. He was running on nothing.

Then, the soft, familiar notes of the introduction to 'Try a Little Tenderness' floated out from the house band. The simple piano melody was a balm, a familiar friend in this terrifyingly alien environment. He gripped the microphone, the metal cool and solid in his sweaty palm. He brought it to his lips. This was it. No more hiding. No more rowing backwards. He had to face the music. He took a breath, not the sharp, gasping breath of a rower, but a slow, deep intake from the diaphragm, just as he'd practiced in the front seat of The Biscuit Tin. He thought of his mother, of Claire and Leo, of the quiet lad from Whittington Moor who had a secret to tell. And he sang. The first line was quiet, almost hesitant, his voice husky with nerves and fatigue. *“Oh, she may be weary…”* The sound felt small, swallowed by the vastness of the hall. He could feel the judges shifting, perhaps sensing his lack of power, and a cold spike of fear lanced through him. He was failing. Claire’s insane plan was crumbling.

But then he sang the next line. *“...and young girls, they do get weary, wearing that same old shabby dress.”* He wasn't just singing the words; he was living them. He *was* weary. He felt the truth of it in his aching back, in the burn in his thighs. The raw honesty of his own physical state connected with the song's emotion, and something shifted. He wasn't performing anymore; he was testifying. He drew on the rower's discipline, the ingrained ability to push through pain, to find another gear when the body is screaming to stop. He channelled that grit not into an oar, but into his voice. As the song began its famous build, the horns kicking in, his voice found its true place. It deepened, strengthened, filled with a richness and power that surprised even him. It was the sound he had found in his living room, but amplified, electrified by the stage and the moment.

He felt the atmosphere in the hall change. The silence was no longer empty; it was charged, attentive. He could feel thousands of people leaning in, listening. He risked a glance at the judges' table. The woman who had called him a geological anomaly was leaning forward, her glasses pushed up on her head, her mouth slightly agape. He had their attention. The song moved into its final, explosive section. It was now or never. He let go of the last vestiges of control, the last shred of self-consciousness. He poured the exhaustion, the conflict, the hope, the grief for his mother, the love for his sister, all of it, into the music. *“You got to, got to, got to… try a little tenderness!”* The words were a roar, a desperate, passionate plea torn from the very soles of his feet. It was the raw, unvarnished sound of his soul. He held the final, soaring note until his lungs burned and his vision swam, giving every last ounce of breath and energy he possessed. Then, as the band crashed to a halt, he let the microphone drop to his side, his chest heaving, his head bowed, utterly spent. For a heartbeat, there was absolute, profound silence. Then, the darkness in front of him erupted. The sound of a thousand people on their feet, the roar of applause and cheers, hit him like a tidal wave, a thunderous, undeniable answer to the question he had been too afraid to ask.

The wave of sound was a physical thing, washing over him, pressing him down. Liam stood with his head bowed, his chest a mess of aching muscles and heaving lungs, as the roar of the crowd filled every inch of the vast auditorium. It was nothing like the cheers at a regatta finish line, which were a shared, communal explosion of relief and victory. This was different. This was a thousand separate moments of connection aimed directly at him, a thousand strangers telling him they had heard his secret. He was utterly, profoundly alone in the centre of that storm of approval, and it was the most terrifying and beautiful feeling of his life.

He forced himself to look up, blinking against the stage lights that now seemed less aggressive, more warming. Through the glare, he could see them: a sea of blurred, smiling faces, a forest of hands clapping above their heads. People were standing not just in the front rows, but all the way to the back of the stalls, up into the grand circle. He saw a woman in the third row openly weeping, her friend's arm around her shoulder. He saw a man who looked like a retired steelworker, built like a brick outhouse, nodding slowly, a look of profound respect on his weathered face. It was too much to process. It was a language of emotion he was only just beginning to understand.

The show’s host, a man with a smile so bright it seemed to have its own power source, glided over and put a companionable arm around Liam's shoulders. The gesture felt strange against his sweat-dampened suit. "Liam Kenna, ladies and gentlemen! Let's hear it one more time!" The host held his microphone out to the audience, and the roar swelled again. "Wow," the host said, his voice a professional blend of awe and bonhomie. "Liam, I think it's safe to say you left a piece of your soul on that stage tonight. The judges are speechless, but I'm going to make them speak. Let's go to the panel." The lights shifted, and Liam found himself facing the three silhouettes, now leaning forward into their own pools of light.

The woman who had peered at him over her glasses in the auditions spoke first, her voice hushed with emotion. "Liam, I've been doing this a long time. I have heard technically perfect singers, I have heard powerful singers, and I have heard singers with great stage presence. It is a rare, rare thing to hear a singer with truth. What you did with that song... it wasn't a performance. It was a confession. It was the most honest three and a half minutes of music I have ever had the privilege to witness on this stage." The other judges echoed her sentiments, speaking of vocal power and emotional depth, but Liam barely heard their words. He was fixated on the phrase 'a singer with truth'. It resonated deep within him, naming the very thing he had been striving for without even knowing it. He mumbled his thanks, his head swimming, the words of praise blurring into the applause, all of it becoming a single, overwhelming sensory experience.

He walked off the stage in a daze, guided by a gentle hand on his back. The applause followed him into the wings, finally fading as he passed back into the glitter-and-hairspray chaos of the backstage area. The atmosphere had changed. The other contestants, his rivals, no longer looked at him with polite curiosity. They looked at him with wide-eyed awe. A couple of them patted him on the back as he passed, murmuring "Incredible, man," and "That was something else." The praise from his peers, who knew what it took to stand on that stage, felt more real than the roar of the crowd. He found his quiet corner behind the flight cases and sagged against the cool wall. And then, as if a switch had been flicked, the adrenaline vanished. A wave of exhaustion so profound it was nauseating washed through him. His legs began to tremble uncontrollably. The aches from his two rowing sessions, which had been masked by the stage lights, returned with a ferocious, biting intensity. He was no longer a showstopper; he was just an exhausted athlete who had pushed himself far, far beyond his limits.

He knew he couldn't stay. He couldn't wait for the public vote, for the final results. His grand final was over, but his ordeal was not. He had another race to run. He found the harried stage manager, who was now looking at him with a new level of respect. "I have to go," he said, the lie feeling worn and familiar now. "Family emergency." She nodded instantly, her expression full of sympathy. "Of course. Oh, gosh, I'm so sorry. Is everything okay? We'll call you, of course. You're... you're a shoo-in for the top two, at least." He just nodded, unable to think about winning. "Thank you," he managed, before slipping out of a heavy fire door and back into the anonymity of the Sheffield night. The cool air was a shock. The sounds of the city felt muted and distant. He walked back to the aggressively beige hotel, his movements slow and stiff, a man twice his age. He changed out of the charcoal suit with a tenderness that bordered on reverence, folding it carefully, as if it were a relic from a life he had lived only for a single evening.

The Biscuit Tin started on the fourth try, its phlegmy roar a welcome, familiar sound in the silent hotel car park. The journey back to Nottingham was a surreal battle against sleep. With the windows down and the cold night air blasting his face, he drove south on a near-empty M1. The motorway lights became hypnotic, dangerous comets streaking past. He cranked the radio, a cacophony of late-night pop and talk shows filling the small car, a desperate attempt to keep the fog of exhaustion at bay. He drank the last of the lukewarm water from his bottle and thought of Dave's cold stare. *Seven a.m.* The deadline was a beacon in the darkness, a point on the map he had to reach. It was the most gruelling endurance event of his life, a slow, rattling crawl back to his other reality.

When he finally pulled into the deserted car park at Holme Pierrepont, it was almost two in the morning. The facility was a collection of dark, brutalist shapes under a cold, starry sky. The silence was absolute, a crushing weight after the noise of the city, the stage, and his rattling car. He felt like an astronaut returning to a silent, sleeping earth after a mission to a loud and vibrant planet. He let himself into his shared room, moving with practiced stealth. His roommate was a dark lump under a thin duvet, his deep, rhythmic breathing the only sound. Liam didn't have the energy to undress. He kicked off his battered trainers, peeled off his jeans, and collapsed onto the narrow, unyielding mattress in his hoodie and t-shirt. Sleep, he thought, would be a mercy, a sweet oblivion. But it wouldn't come. His body was a thrumming network of aches and pains, and his mind was a battlefield. The roar of the crowd clashed with the squeak of his oarlocks. His mother’s smile flickered behind his eyelids, followed by Dave’s unimpressed glower. He lay in the darkness, trapped between two worlds, too tired to sleep, too wired to rest, as the precious hours ticked away.

The shrill, digital scream of his phone alarm at six o’clock was an act of violence. For a moment, he had no idea where he was. The thin, grey light, the smell of damp sportswear, the spartan room—it all came flooding back with a crushing weight. He swung his legs over the side of the bed and every muscle in his body screamed in a unified chorus of protest. He felt brittle, scoured out, profoundly unwell. He stumbled to the small sink and looked in the mirror. The man who stared back was a stranger. His face was pale and drawn, his eyes bloodshot and sunk deep in their sockets, circled by bruises of exhaustion. The victorious singer, the man who had looked so sharp in a charcoal suit, was gone. In his place was a haggard, haunted-looking rower on the verge of collapse. He pulled on his lycra, the tight fabric feeling less like a second skin and more like a straitjacket. He was an empty cup, and he was about to be asked to pour a gallon. The time was 6:35 a.m. His reckoning with Dave was less than half an hour away.

The walk from his room to the boathouse felt like crossing a vast, unforgiving desert. The concrete path was a mile long, the damp morning air a physical weight on his chest. Other rowers, fresh from a full night's sleep, jogged past him, their bodies loose and ready, their banter sharp and bright in the pre-dawn gloom. They were coiled springs, and he was a length of frayed, overstretched rope. He nodded and grunted in response to their "Morning, Kenna" greetings, his own voice a dry rasp. He felt their glances linger on him, noting the pallor of his skin, the dark hollows under his eyes. He was a piece of faulty equipment, a boat with a slow leak, and everyone could see it.

He found his scull, a sleek black needle of carbon fibre that usually felt like an extension of his own body. This morning, it felt alien, a finely-tuned instrument he no longer knew how to play. As he began checking his riggers, a shadow fell over him. It was Dave. The coach stood with his arms crossed, a steaming mug of tea in one hand, a stopwatch in the other. He didn't speak for a long moment, simply observing Liam's slow, stiff movements. His silence was more damning than any tirade.

"The christening go well, Kenna?" Dave asked, his voice deceptively mild, the gravelly edge smoothed away into something far more dangerous. "Must have been a long service. You look like you've been wrestling with the devil all night and lost."

Liam’s hands froze on the rigger bolt. He couldn’t bring himself to look up. "It was... a long drive, coach," he mumbled to the hull of his boat.

"Right," Dave said, taking a slow sip of his tea. "A long drive." He took a step closer, lowering his voice so only Liam could hear. "I don't know where you were last night, son. And right now, I don't care. All I care about is what happens in the next seven minutes on that stretch of water. You told me you wouldn't be tired. You're a liar. Your face is a mess, and you look like you're about to fall over. But you're here. You're in your kit. So you're going to race." He pointed the stopwatch at Liam like a weapon. "This little clock doesn't care about your excuses. It only tells the truth. Let's see what kind of truth you've got left in you."

He walked away without another word, leaving Liam feeling stripped bare, his lie exposed and worthless. The coach knew. He knew he'd been played for a fool, and now he was going to watch Liam pay the price in the only currency that mattered: time. The shame was a physical burn, worse than the ache in his muscles. He felt a surge of anger—at Dave, at Claire, but mostly at himself for thinking he could pull this off. He finished his preparations on autopilot, his mind a numb void, and carried his boat to the pontoon. The water was flat and grey, a black mirror that reflected the miserable sky. It felt like an ending.

Pushing off from the pontoon, he paddled slowly towards the start line. Each stroke was a negotiation with his protesting body. His back was a rigid plank, his legs felt like they were filled with wet sand, and his head throbbed in time with his strained heartbeat. He lined up next to the other single scullers, each man in his own lane, a picture of coiled, focused power. Liam felt like a ghost among them. When the starter's electronic horn blared, his body reacted out of pure, deep-seated instinct. He launched into the first powerful strokes, the initial 'drive' phase of the race. But the explosion he expected from his legs wasn't there. It was a dull, muffled push. The boat felt heavy, sluggish, stuck in the water. Within two hundred metres, he could see the other scullers pulling away from him, their puddles of disturbed water already a boat-length ahead. The panic he’d been holding at bay crashed over him. He was failing. Publicly and spectacularly.

The first five hundred metres were a private hell. His technique, usually so fluid and powerful, fell apart. He was pulling with his arms, his back straining, his legs unresponsive. The digital monitor at his feet showed a split time that was five, then six, then seven seconds slower than his worst training pace. It was a time that would see him relegated to the second boat, his season’s ambitions turning to dust. He could almost feel Dave’s cold, triumphant gaze from the towpath. *This is what you get for your lies. This is the truth.* The thought made him want to stop, to just let the oars drift and slump over, defeated. But then another voice cut through the fog of pain and shame. A judge's voice. *A singer with truth.*

What was the truth now? The truth was that he was exhausted. The truth was that he was in pain. The truth was that he was failing. He had sung that truth last night. He hadn't hidden his weariness; he had poured it into the song. Could he do that here? Could he row the truth? He stopped fighting his body, stopped trying to force a power that wasn't there. He eased off for a single stroke, taking one deep, ragged breath. He closed his eyes and thought not of the finish line, but of the stage lights. He thought of the roar of the crowd, the feeling of a thousand people hearing him, really hearing him. He remembered the raw, desperate cry of Otis Redding's voice, the sheer force of will that pushed the song to its climax. *Got to, got to, got to...*

The phrase became a mantra, a new rhythm for the boat. He found a different gear, not of power, but of relentless, stubborn endurance. He stopped thinking about his split time and started thinking about the beat. *Catch... (Got to)... Drive... (Got to)... Finish... (Got to)... Recover.* His strokes were not beautiful. They were not efficient. They were ugly, guttural, a raw and desperate heave. He was no longer a technician; he was a labourer, digging his blades into the water and dragging the boat forward with whatever he had left. He was rowing with his heart, with the memory of the song, with the ghost of his mother’s pride. He was channelling the singer, the man who stood and delivered when he had nothing left, into the rower's exhausted body.

He didn't know if he was getting faster. He had stopped looking at the monitor. His world had shrunk to the grey water, the hiss of the hull, and the three-word mantra driving him forward. He entered the final five hundred metres, the 'red zone' where races are won and lost. A primal roar built in his chest. He pulled with a ferocity that came from somewhere beyond his muscles, from the same deep well of emotion he had drawn from on stage. He saw the orange buoys of the finish line, a blurred smear in his tunnel vision. He pulled one last, agonising stroke, then another, and then he was through. He collapsed forward, the oars slipping from his numb fingers, his head and chest slumping onto the deck of the boat. He lay there, gasping, his body convulsing, utterly and completely spent. He had nothing left. He had given the water the only truth he had.

The world returned to Liam in fragments. First, the frantic, scraping sound of his own breathing. Then, the gentle slap of water against the hull of the scull, a sound that was usually a comfort but now felt like a mocking pat on the back. A profound trembling started in his legs and spread through his entire body, a seismic release of a strain his system could no longer contain. He tried to sit up, to regain some semblance of a rower's posture, but his core muscles refused the command, sending sharp, protesting signals of failure. He remained slumped over, his cheek pressed against the cold, wet carbon fibre, a beached whale in a skin-tight suit. He had rowed the truth, and the truth had broken him.

He heard the gentle crunch of footsteps on the gravel towpath, slowing and then stopping beside his boat. He didn't need to look up to know who it was. The silence that followed was heavy and absolute, a judgment in itself. Liam squeezed his eyes shut, bracing for the inevitable storm of Dave’s fury. He deserved it. He had lied, he had been foolish, and he had posted a time that was almost certainly a disgrace.

"Your time was four seconds off your personal best."

The statement was so unexpected, so contrary to the catastrophe he had felt, that Liam thought he had misheard. He pushed himself up with a groan, his arms shaking, and finally looked at his coach. Dave was standing there, staring not at Liam, but at the stopwatch in his hand, his brow furrowed as if the device had presented him with an impossible paradox. Four seconds. It wasn't good. For an elite rower, it was a significant margin. But it wasn't the disaster Liam had expected. It wasn't the time of a man who should have been ten, fifteen seconds slower. It was the time of a man who had fought.

"I don't know how," Dave said, finally looking up. His gaze was no longer cold or angry. It was something far more unnerving: analytical and intensely curious. "For the first six hundred metres, you were rowing like a novice. You were tense, your rhythm was shot, you were bleeding speed with every stroke. I was about to pull you off the course. And then... something changed. Your technique was still a mess. It was ugly. But your power output spiked. You held it all the way to the line. It was the ugliest, most inefficient, most stubborn piece of rowing I have ever seen in my life." He paused, shaking his head slightly. "So I'll ask you again. Where were you last night, Kenna?"

The lie had dissolved. There was no point to it anymore. Liam let out a long, shuddering breath that was half-sob, half-laugh. "I was in Sheffield. At the City Hall. I was in the final of a singing competition." He said the words to the water, to the boat, to himself as much as to Dave. They sounded even more ridiculous out loud in the cold morning light.

Dave was silent for a long moment. He looked from Liam's haggard face to the boat, then back again, as if trying to reconcile the two realities. "Right," he said, the single word laden with a decade of accumulated disbelief. He tucked the stopwatch into his pocket. "A singing competition." He didn't mock. He didn't shout. He just stated it as a fact he was now forced to incorporate into his worldview. "Get your boat out of the water. You look like death. Go and get something to eat. And then you and I are going to have a conversation about your commitment to this crew." He turned and walked away, his stiff-backed posture radiating a complex mix of disappointment and reluctant respect that was far more potent than pure anger.

The act of getting the boat out of the water was a Herculean effort. Mark, his face a mixture of concern and mischievous curiosity, came to help him lift the scull onto the trestles. "Blimey, Liam. That christening take it out of you? You look like you've been on a three-day bender with the devil's choir." Liam just grunted, his body too broken for banter. As he wiped down the hull, his hands moving with slow, deliberate care, news of his performance began to ripple through the squad. Whispers followed him into the changing rooms. Someone had seen an article on a local news site. Someone else had a cousin who'd been watching. The secret was out, and it was spreading like wildfire.

He collapsed onto a bench, peeling off his wet lycra with a groan. His phone lay in the bottom of his bag, a small, black rectangle of judgement. He had deliberately ignored it, terrified of what it might tell him. Had he won? Had he lost? Had he made a fool of himself in front of a television audience? Part of him didn't want to know. The performance itself, the act of singing his truth, felt like the only thing that mattered. The result was just an administrative detail. But he was also human. He had to know. With trembling fingers, he pulled it out. The screen lit up with a blizzard of notifications. Dozens of WhatsApp messages from the club group chat, a flurry of texts, and five missed calls from Claire. And one email. The subject line read: *A Message from the Voice of the Peaks Team.*

His heart hammered against his ribs. He ignored Claire's calls for a moment and opened the email.

*Dear Liam,*
*On behalf of the entire production, we wanted to thank you for what was, by any measure, one of the most memorable and moving final performances we have ever had. The public vote was incredibly close. In the end, the title of Voice of the Peaks 2024 was awarded to Sasha Jones. We are absolutely thrilled, however, to name you as our runner-up. The judges were unanimous in their praise for your unique talent and emotional honesty...*

Runner-up. He read the words again. Not the winner. He felt a sharp, surprising pang of disappointment, a competitor’s instinctive reaction to second place. He had lost. But as he read on, the formal, corporate language of the email faded, and the meaning settled in. Runner-up. In a real, televised singing competition. He, Liam Kenna, the quiet lad from the canal. A smile, slow and genuine, spread across his exhausted face. He hadn't won. And it was okay. More than okay. It was brilliant. He hadn't failed. He had stood on a stage and sung his heart out and people had listened. He had raced in a boat when his body was broken and had found a way not to quit. In a single, impossible twenty-four-hour period, he had come in second in two different lives, and somehow, it felt more like a victory than any gold medal he had ever won. He leaned his head back against the cold tiles of the changing room wall and closed his eyes, the roar of the crowd and the hiss of his hull on the water finally finding a strange, quiet harmony in his mind.

He let his head rest against the cool, damp tiles of the changing room wall for a long moment, the phone still clutched in his hand. Runner-up. The two words seemed to hum with a quiet, steady energy, a counterbalance to the screaming exhaustion in his limbs. Before he could overthink it, before the disappointment could curdle the strange joy, he tapped on Claire’s name and raised the phone to his ear. It was answered before the first ring had even finished, an explosion of sound that made him pull the receiver away from his head.

"LIAM! OH MY GOD, LIAM! YOU WERE AMAZING! I'M CRYING, LEO'S HYPERVENTILATING, DAD ACTUALLY SMILED! WE WERE AT THE RUTLAND AND THE ENTIRE PUB WENT SILENT WHEN YOU STARTED, AND THEN WHEN YOU FINISHED, THEY WERE STANDING ON THE TABLES! ON THE TABLES, LIAM! I'VE GOT IT ON VIDEO! YOU WERE ROBBED, ABSOLUTELY ROBBED, BUT WHO CARES, YOU WERE INCREDIBLE!"

Her voice, a breathless, joyous torrent, was the purest form of victory he could imagine. He found himself laughing, a cracked, hoarse sound that hurt his throat but felt wonderful. "Claire, calm down," he managed, his own voice thick with emotion. "I can't... I didn't win, Claire."

"Don't you dare say that!" she retorted, her voice fierce with pride. "You won. You walked onto that stage looking like James Bond's bigger, better-looking brother from Derbyshire, and you sang like an absolute god. Everyone knows you won. Sasha was brilliant, but you... you were something else. You were real. Mum would have... she would have been so, so proud." There was a catch in her voice now, and Liam felt his own eyes sting. In the background, he could hear Leo shouting, "Uncle Liam is a pop star! He's a pop star!"

He stayed on the phone for ten minutes, basking in the uncomplicated warmth of his sister’s pride, letting it soak into his bones and begin the slow work of healing his frayed spirit. She told him about the prize—a recording session at a professional studio and a not-insignificant sum of money that would more than cover the cost of a new engine for The Biscuit Tin. The practicalities of it were grounding, making the dreamlike events of the night before feel solid and tangible. When he finally hung up, the small, sterile changing room no longer felt like a cell. It felt like a chrysalis from which he was, painfully and slowly, beginning to emerge.

He dressed with the deliberate movements of an old man, pulling on his jeans and a clean hoodie. When he finally pushed open the door and walked back into the main boathouse, the atmosphere had undergone a seismic shift. The earlier whispers had been replaced by a quiet, buzzing curiosity. A group of the younger rowers stopped their conversation and just watched him walk past. Mark detached himself from a group and came over, phone in hand, a wide, incredulous grin on his face.

"Kenna," he said, shaking his head in disbelief. "I've got three missed calls from my wife. She says if I don't get your autograph, I'm sleeping in the shed." He held up his phone, showing Liam a clip from the final, filmed from a TV screen. It was the climax of the song, his face contorted in a mask of raw emotion, his voice a powerful roar that seemed impossible coming from the exhausted man standing there now. "Mate, we all thought you were just a big lump who could pull an oar. We didn't know you had *that* in you. That was... mega." Another rower, one of the serious, taciturn giants from the coxless four, clapped him on the shoulder, a gesture that almost sent Liam staggering. "Good on you, mate," he said, his voice gruff with an approval that meant more than a thousand standing ovations. They didn't mock him. They didn't see weakness. They saw a different kind of strength, and in their own blunt, understated way, they were in awe of it.

The final trial, however, was yet to come. Dave’s office was a small, cluttered cave at the end of the boathouse, a place smelling of old paper, damp wool, and industrial-strength coffee. Race plans and tide tables were pinned to a corkboard, and trophies from bygone eras gathered dust on a high shelf. It was the nerve centre of Dave's world. Liam knocked on the open door. Dave was at his desk, staring at a spreadsheet on his computer screen. He didn’t look up. "Shut the door," he said. The quiet command sent a chill through Liam. He did as he was told, the click of the latch sounding unnervingly final.

"So," Dave began, swivelling his chair around. "You're a singer." He said the word 'singer' as if it were a newly discovered species of insect he was trying to classify. "You lied to me, you jeopardised your place in the boat, you risked the whole crew's performance at the regatta, and you turned up this morning looking like something the cat dragged in. All for a karaoke contest."

Liam stood before the desk, his hands hanging uselessly at his sides. He didn't offer an excuse. He owed his coach the truth, ugly and complicated as it was. "It wasn't karaoke, coach. And it wasn't just for a contest." He took a breath. "My mum... she loved music. We used to sing all the time. After she died, the house went quiet. Singing those old songs was... it was my way of remembering her. Of keeping that part of her alive. It was just for me. I never meant for it to become this." He gestured vaguely, indicating the whole impossible situation. "But it did. And last night, I had to see it through. I had to."

Dave listened, his expression unreadable, his steepled fingers hiding his mouth. He was a man who dealt in quantifiable metrics: power, speed, endurance. He was being presented with data he couldn't plot on a graph. "Your mother," he said, his voice losing some of its edge. "She was a good woman. Came to every race." The unexpected memory seemed to hang in the air between them. He looked down at his desk, at the spreadsheet of split times and power curves, then back up at Liam.

"I saw the video," Dave admitted, his voice low. "Mark showed me. In the final minute of that race this morning, when you had nothing left, your face looked exactly like it did on that stage. Like you were tearing it out of yourself. I've spent ten years trying to teach you how to dig that deep, how to find that place where you go beyond what you think you're capable of. And you found it. Not on the water. But in a theatre, singing some old love song." He leaned back in his chair, a long, slow sigh escaping him. It was the sound of a fundamental belief system rearranging itself. "I don't understand it. And I don't have to. But I saw what it did for you this morning. You should have been dead on your feet. You should have been fifteen seconds slower. But you weren't. You found a way."

He stood up and walked to the corkboard, staring at the crew list for the Northern Regatta. Liam’s name was at the top, under 'Single Scull' and 'Coxless Four'. "Your place in this boat isn't about loyalty, Kenna. It's about speed. And it's my job to make you faster. If singing songs in a suit makes you faster, then sing your bloody songs." He turned around, his eyes locking with Liam’s. There was no smile, but the hard, flinty disappointment was gone, replaced by a new, grudging understanding. "But if your time slips by even one second because of it, you're out. And you're cleaning the toilets for a month. Are we clear?"

"Crystal, coach," Liam said, the relief so profound it felt like a physical release, a muscle unclenched after a decade of tension.

He walked out of Dave's office and back into the boathouse, which was now bustling with the post-training activity of a normal Sunday morning. But nothing felt normal. He felt lighter, as if he'd been rowing with a weighted vest on for years and had only just taken it off. He walked out of the boathouse doors and into the full light of the day. The sun had finally broken through the grey cloud, and the river, his place of work and worship, shimmered with a new, welcoming brilliance. He got into The Biscuit Tin and turned the key. The engine, for once, started on the first try, settling into a steady, reliable rattle. He pulled out of the car park and onto the open road, driving not towards home, but just driving. He didn't turn on the radio. He didn't need to. For the first time, there was no conflict, no counter-rhythm. There was only the steady beat of the engine and the quiet, harmonious rhythm of his own heart, a rhythm that finally belonged to a man who was whole.

The road back to Chesterfield unravelled before The Biscuit Tin in a ribbon of grey tarmac under a now-brilliant sky. The familiar landmarks of his home county—a distant view of Bolsover Castle, the gentle roll of the fields near Calow—seemed new, as if he were seeing them for the first time with both eyes open. The profound exhaustion remained, a deep, resonant hum in his bones, but the frantic, panicked edge had gone. It was a clean fatigue, the satisfying ache of a body and soul that had been pushed to their absolute limits and had, somehow, held. He felt scoured clean, hollowed out, but ready to be filled again. For the first time in as long as he could remember, there was no war inside his head. There was only a quiet, spacious peace.

He pulled into a lay-by that overlooked the valley where the town was nestled, the crooked spire a familiar, reassuring punctuation mark against the sky. He killed the engine and the sudden silence was welcome. He scrolled through his phone and found his dad’s number. He hesitated for a moment. Their calls were usually brief, functional affairs about shopping lists or boiler repairs. Since his mum had died, they communicated mostly through a shared, unspoken grief, a quiet understanding that the most important thing had been taken from their lives and words were a poor substitute. But Claire had said he’d smiled. That single image was an invitation. He pressed the call button.

It rang four times before his dad picked up, his voice a gruff, questioning "Liam?"
"Hi, Dad. I'm on my way back," Liam said, his own voice sounding foreign, softer than usual.
"Right," his dad replied. A pause stretched between them, filled with the static of years of unsaid things. Liam could picture him perfectly, sitting in his worn armchair, the remote control on the arm, the racing pages open on his lap.
"Claire said you were at The Rutland last night," Liam prompted gently.
Another pause. "Aye. Place was packed. Had to stand."
"Oh. Right." Liam searched for what to say next. "So... you saw it then?"
"I saw it," his dad confirmed. The silence that followed was different this time. It felt less like an absence and more like a space being held. Liam waited. "That song," his dad said finally, his voice thick, as if the words were being dredged up from a deep, rusty well. "That Otis Redding one. Your mother loved that song. Used to play it on the record player on a Sunday morning while she was cooking."

The simple statement landed with the force of a revelation. It was an acknowledgement, a connection, a shared memory offered up like a priceless gift. It was his father’s way of saying *I heard you. I understood.* It was everything. "Yeah," Liam managed, his throat tight. "Yeah, I know, Dad."
"You did alright," his dad added, the highest praise in his limited emotional vocabulary. "She'd have liked it." And then, as if he had expended his entire quota of sentiment for the decade, he cleared his throat. "Your auntie Jean's asking if you can take a look at her lawnmower next week. Says it's making a funny noise." The familiar territory of the mundane was a relief for both of them. They talked for another minute about the lawnmower, then said their goodbyes. Liam ended the call and leaned his forehead against the steering wheel, a single, hot tear tracing a path through the grime on his cheek. He hadn't won a trophy, but he had gotten his dad to talk about a Sunday morning.

When he finally pulled up outside his small terraced house, it felt more like a home than it had in years. The silence within its walls was no longer one of absence, but one of peace. He walked into the living room and his eyes went straight to the mantelpiece, to the crowded rowing trophies standing guard around the single, faded photograph of his mother. She was smiling, her head tilted slightly, a look of amused affection in her eyes. He felt he could finally meet her gaze without the familiar, accompanying pang of guilt for all the music that had died with her. He had sung her song. He had brought it back. He walked upstairs, stripped off his clothes, and fell into bed. The sleep that took him was not the fitful, anxious rest of a man at war with himself, but a deep, dreamless, healing oblivion.

He woke hours later to the gentle light of late afternoon slanting through his window and the persistent buzzing of his phone on the bedside table. He felt groggy but fundamentally different, as if some crucial part of his internal machinery had been taken out, cleaned, and slotted back into its rightful place. The phone buzzed again. It was a message from Mark. *'The video of you in the final is doing the rounds on a massive rowing forum. They're calling you The Sculling Soulman. You're a legend, mate.'* Liam stared at the words, a slow smile spreading across his face. The Sculling Soulman. It was ridiculous, but it was also perfect. He was no longer two separate, warring entities. He was one thing.

Curiosity finally got the better of him. He showered, pulled on a pair of old jeans and a t-shirt, and walked down to the corner shop for a pint of milk and a newspaper. He felt a strange self-consciousness as he walked, a new awareness of how people saw him. He was no longer anonymous. As he put the milk on the counter, the woman behind the till, Mrs. Evans, a woman who had sold him sweets and comics since he was Leo’s age, peered at him over her glasses. "It is you!" she exclaimed, her voice loud in the quiet shop. "Off the telly last night! Oh, you were wonderful, love! Had a tear in my eye. You were robbed, you were. That girl was good, but you... you had soul!" She leaned forward conspiratorially. "My Brenda's getting married in August. We need a wedding singer..." Liam laughed, a genuine, easy laugh, feeling a blush creep up his neck. He stammered something about being busy with training and made his escape, clutching his milk and the local paper, his heart thumping with a strange mixture of embarrassment and pleasure. The secret was out, and he was beginning to realize that maybe it wasn't a cage he had escaped, but a door he had finally walked through. His secret garden now had an open gate.

Back home, the newspaper sat on his kitchen table, its headline a testament to the surreal turn his life had taken. *‘Local Rower’s Soulful Surprise at Peaks Final’*. There was a slightly grainy picture of him on stage, his face a mask of passion, the smart charcoal suit looking impossibly formal. He read the article, a mixture of local news reporting and breathless praise, and it felt like reading about a stranger. He had spent his entire adult life cultivating a kind of invisibility, his identity defined by the brute, anonymous force required to move a boat backwards. To be seen so clearly, to have the most private part of himself laid bare for public consumption, was a dizzying, disorienting experience. The quiet lad from Whittington Moor was gone, and in his place was this ‘Sculling Soulman’, a public figure, albeit on a very small, very local scale. He wasn't sure if he was ready for the promotion.

The following Tuesday, as he walked into the boathouse for the evening session, the change was palpable. Someone had pinned the newspaper article to the club noticeboard, right next to the regatta sign-up sheets. As he passed, a young novice rower, barely eighteen, nervously asked him to sign the edge of the clipping. The request was so absurd that Liam almost laughed, but the boy’s earnest, hero-worshipping expression stopped him. He scribbled his name awkwardly with a biro, his signature looking clunky and unfamiliar, the scrawl of a man more used to gripping an oar than a pen. The old locker room banter had shifted, too. The usual jibes about his pre-dawn training or his monstrous appetite had been replaced by a new, recurring theme. As he was changing, Mark's phone, placed pointedly on a bench, began to play the opening bars of 'Try a Little Tenderness'. A ripple of snickering went through the room. Liam, expecting the familiar hot blush of embarrassment, was surprised to find himself just shaking his head and smiling. The joke had lost its power to wound him; the secret was no longer his to protect.

He carried that new, lighter feeling with him down to the water. As he launched his scull into the cool, dark river, the evening felt charged with a different kind of energy. For years, these sessions had been a form of penance, a physical grind to atone for a day spent sitting at a desk. Now, it felt like something else. It felt like expression. He pushed off, the boat gliding smoothly, and as he began to row, he didn't fight the music in his head. He invited it in. The catch, the drive, the finish, the recovery—it was no longer just a sequence of movements. It was a four-beat bar of music. He found the rhythm of the song that was always playing in his mind, Al Green's 'Let's Stay Together', and matched his stroke to its steady, soulful pulse. He wasn't rowing against his nature anymore; he was rowing with it. The boat seemed to respond, surging forward with a smooth, powerful grace that felt effortless, a perfect harmony of muscle and melody.

Dave stood on the towpath, his familiar silhouette a fixed point in the deepening dusk. Liam was doing timed one-thousand-metre pieces, and he knew the coach's stopwatch was tracking every stroke. He finished his first piece, his breathing deep but controlled, his muscles burning with a clean, efficient fire. He paddled gently, waiting for the inevitable critique to be barked across the water. But it didn't come. Dave just clicked his stopwatch and made a note on his clipboard. "Again," was all he shouted. Liam completed a second piece, and a third, each one feeling as strong and fluid as the last, his body and mind working in a rare, seamless partnership. As he paddled back towards the boathouse, Dave walked alongside him on the path. "Your consistency has improved," the coach grunted, his gaze fixed straight ahead. "Your times for those three pieces were within half a second of each other. Strong times." He was silent for a few paces. "I got a call," he said, so quietly Liam had to strain to hear. "From a fella at the National Rowing Magazine. They want to do a feature. On the club. On you. 'The Singing Rower Who Found An Extra Gear'." Dave said the phrase with the same distaste as if he were describing a piece of mouldy bread. "I told them to call back next week."

Later that evening, Claire came over, brandishing a bottle of Prosecco and a USB stick. "Official celebration," she announced, shooing him onto the sofa. "Dad's babysitting, the hype has died down just enough for us to have a proper moment, and I have the evidence." She plugged the stick into his television, and a shaky, cacophonous video filled the screen. It was the footage from The Rutland Arms. He watched, mesmerised, as the camera panned across the packed pub, across the faces of people he'd known his whole life. He saw his neighbours, old school friends, fellow parents from Leo's football team, all of them standing, their conversations stilled, their eyes fixed on the pub's television where his own face was singing. And then the camera found his dad, standing by the bar, a half-empty pint in his hand, his expression uncharacteristically open, his gaze locked on the screen. He wasn't smiling, but he was *watching*. He was present. As the song on the television reached its climax, the pub erupted, a roar of pure, communal joy. Liam watched himself on the screen, a man he barely knew, and then watched the reaction of the people who knew him best, and finally understood. It wasn't about the prize, or the judges, or the fame. It was about this. It was about connection. It was about making the people in your small corner of the world feel something.

The bottle of Prosecco was half-empty when he finally checked his emails. Tucked between work memos and spam was a message from a 'Phoenix Sound Studios'. The email was professional and to the point, detailing the prize: two full eight-hour days in a state-of-the-art studio with a house producer to record and mix two songs of his choice. They proposed a weekend a month from now. A month. It seemed both an age away and terrifyingly close. "Two songs," he said out loud, the words feeling heavy and significant. "What would I even sing?" The first was obvious. 'Try a Little Tenderness' was his song now, the anthem of his transformation. But the second? He needed something that wasn't a showstopper, something that showed a different side. Something quieter, more intimate. He thought of his dad's words, of the Sunday mornings of his childhood. "Claire," he said, turning to his sister, who was happily scrolling through comments on the pub video. "Do you remember that Sam Cooke song Mum always used to sing when she was trying to get us to tidy our rooms? The one she'd change the words to?" Claire looked up, her brow furrowed in concentration for a moment before her face lit up. "A Change Is Gonna Come," she said, her voice soft. "She used to sing 'A change is gonna come... to this messy bedroom'." The memory, so specific and so tender, was perfect. It was a song of struggle, but also of profound hope. It was a conversation with his mother, and a promise to himself.

He drove to his morning session a few days later, The Biscuit Tin rattling along the quiet Derbyshire lanes. The radio was on, playing some forgettable chart song, but Liam wasn't listening. He was humming, a low baritone rumble in his chest. He was working through the melody of 'A Change Is Gonna Come', feeling its gentle rise and fall, its quiet power. He pulled into the boathouse car park and saw Mark getting his boat off his car roof. Mark heard the humming as Liam got out of the car and grinned. "Morning, Sculling Soulman. Warming up the golden pipes?" Two months ago, the comment would have sent Liam into a spiral of self-conscious silence. This morning, he just smiled back. "Got to, mate," he said, his voice easy and confident. "Big session ahead." He walked towards the boathouse, the melody still on his lips, the cool morning air filling his lungs, ready for the work. He was no longer two halves of a person fighting for control. He was a rower. He was a singer. And for the first time, it felt like the most natural thing in the world.

The week between the regatta and the recording session passed in a dreamlike haze. The gold medal, heavy and cool, sat on his mantelpiece, but it felt different from the others. It wasn't just a symbol of physical victory; it was a validation of his entire, chaotic journey. It was a tangible piece of proof that the Sculling Soulman was not a novelty act, but a formidable competitor. The win had cemented his status at the club, transforming him from a curiosity into a quiet leader. Younger rowers would ask him for advice, not just on technique, but on managing race-day nerves, their questions betraying a new respect for his mental fortitude. He found he had answers for them, speaking not in the cold, technical terms Dave used, but in metaphors of rhythm and focus that he was only just discovering himself. He was, to his own astonishment, becoming a mentor.

His first act with the prize money was a pilgrimage to a garage on the outskirts of Chesterfield, a place recommended by his dad, run by an old mechanic who allegedly spoke the language of failing engines. Liam left The Biscuit Tin with him, along with a significant portion of his winnings, feeling a strange pang of anxiety, like leaving a sick, elderly relative in a nursing home. He spent the rest of the week borrowing Claire’s car, a sensible, silent Toyota that felt utterly devoid of character. The quiet hum of its modern engine only made him miss the familiar, complaining rattle of his own car. The Biscuit Tin, for all its faults, was part of his story, its percussive engine a backing track to his secret singing practice. He hoped the mechanic wouldn't fix the soul out of it.

He drove to Phoenix Sound Studios on a bright Saturday morning in Claire’s unnervingly reliable car. The studio was located in a converted Victorian mill in a fashionable part of Sheffield, a world of exposed brickwork, artisan coffee shops, and people who looked effortlessly creative. It was a far cry from the functional brutality of Holme Pierrepont or the damp, earthy smell of the Chesterfield canal. Liam walked into the reception area, his old guitar case in one hand—containing not a guitar, but a change of clothes and a packed lunch—and felt a fresh wave of impostor syndrome. The walls were lined with gold and platinum discs, monuments to albums he had grown up with. This was a place where real musicians came, where magic was made, and he was a rower who had gotten lucky on a local TV show.

A young man with bright pink hair and a friendly, open face came out to greet him. "Liam? I'm Ben, the producer. Massive fan of your performance in the final, man. That was epic. Ready to make some noise?" Ben’s easy, unaffected enthusiasm was a welcome antidote to Liam’s nerves. He led him through a corridor and into the main studio. The room took Liam’s breath away. It was a huge, wood-panelled space, dominated by a grand piano and a forest of microphone stands. On the other side of a vast window was the control room, a dizzying array of buttons, faders, and screens that looked like the cockpit of a spaceship. It was both terrifying and beautiful. "Right," Ben said, clapping his hands together. "Let's get some levels. We'll start with 'Tenderness', get you warmed up with the big one. Just stand in the middle there, and sing a bit of the chorus for me."

Liam stood in the centre of the cavernous room, a pair of heavy headphones over his ears. He felt small and exposed under the studio lights. He cleared his throat and sang the explosive climax of the song. The sound in his headphones was extraordinary. It was his own voice, but magnified, clarified, stripped of all echo and room noise. He could hear every breath, every tiny imperfection, every nuance of his tone. It was like seeing his reflection in a perfectly still lake for the first time. For a moment, he faltered, intimidated by the sheer clarity of the sound. "That's great, mate, lovely warm tone," Ben's voice crackled in his ears from the control room. "Don't be afraid of it. Just give it what you gave it on the telly. From the top." Liam took a deep breath, closed his eyes, and sang. He poured the memory of the stage lights, the roar of the crowd, and the recent victory at the regatta into the performance. He sang with a new confidence, a new control, the song feeling less like a desperate plea and more like a joyful declaration.

The day was a revelation. Ben was a genius, a patient and intuitive guide who knew exactly how to get the best out of him. He pushed Liam to try different phrasings, to experiment with the dynamics, to find the quiet vulnerability in the opening verses as well as the raw power in the climax. By lunchtime, they had a vocal take for 'Tenderness' that made the hairs on Liam’s arms stand up. It was him, but it was bigger, better, the version of the song he had always heard in his head but had never quite been able to produce. After a lunch of Claire's cheese-and-pickle sandwiches, they moved on to 'A Change Is Gonna Come'. The atmosphere in the studio shifted. The energetic, rock-and-roll vibe was replaced by a quiet, almost reverent concentration.

This song was harder. It couldn’t be conquered with power; it had to be inhabited with feeling. Liam’s first few takes were technically sound but emotionally hollow. He was singing the notes, but he wasn't telling the story. "Okay, let's take a break," Ben said, his voice calm and encouraging in the headphones. "Tell me about this song. Why did you pick it?" Liam, feeling strangely comfortable in the intimate space created by the headphones, found himself telling Ben about his mum, about the Sunday mornings, about her changing the lyrics to make him tidy his room. He spoke of his dad's reaction, of the feeling of bringing music back into a silent house. Ben listened without interrupting. "Right," he said when Liam had finished. "That's what the song is about. It's not about the civil rights movement, not for you. It's about your mum. It's about your dad. It's about Sunday morning. Forget the studio, forget me. Close your eyes and sing it to her."

Liam stood in the silence of the vocal booth, the weight of the headphones a comforting presence. He closed his eyes and he was no longer in a Sheffield recording studio. He was a small boy again, standing in the doorway of his parents' kitchen, the smell of a roast in the air, the sound of his mother's voice, clear and happy, filling the room. He sang from that place. He sang with a quiet, trembling intensity, his voice imbued with a lifetime of love and loss. The performance was stripped bare of all artifice, a simple, heartbreakingly honest conversation with a memory. When he sang the final, hopeful line, "It's been a long time coming, but I know a change is gonna come," his voice cracked with an emotion he didn't try to hide. He held the last note until it faded into the profound silence of the studio. For a long moment, there was no sound from the control room. Then, Ben's voice came through the headphones, thick with feeling. "Yeah," he said softly. "That's the one."

A month slipped by, the seasons turning in that indecisive way of an English spring shifting towards summer. Life for Liam settled into a new kind of normal, a rhythm that was both familiar and fundamentally altered. The days were still marked by the early morning pilgrimage to the canal and the quiet hum of his office job designing drainage systems for the council, a profession so prosaic it felt like the perfect cover for a man with a secret life. But the secret was out, and the pressure that had built for years inside him had been released, leaving behind a sense of quiet confidence, a comfortable occupation of his own skin. He no longer felt like two people living in one body, but a single man with a wide and varied landscape inside him.

The email from Ben arrived on a Tuesday afternoon, a bright spot in the grey landscape of spreadsheets and technical drawings. The subject line was simple: *'Your Finished Tracks'*. Liam’s heart gave a theatrical lurch. He waited until his colleagues had left for lunch before plugging his headphones into his computer, the office’s low-level hum fading to nothing. He clicked the link for ‘Try a Little Tenderness’ first. The opening piano chords, crisp and clear, filled his ears. Then the bass and drums kicked in, warmer and richer than he remembered. Ben had worked his magic, adding subtle layers of organ and a richer, fuller horn section that made the track swell with a professional, radio-ready polish. And then his own voice entered, deep and resonant. He listened, utterly mesmerised, a strange sense of dissociation washing over him. It was him, undeniably, but it was a version of him amplified and illuminated, the sound of the man he had only just discovered he could be. He was listening to his own potential, recorded and mastered, and it was a humbling, exhilarating experience.

With a trembling finger, he clicked on the second track. The gentle, melancholic guitar intro of 'A Change Is Gonna Come' began, and the mood shifted instantly. Ben had kept the production sparse, creating a vast, intimate space around his voice. He had added a soft halo of strings that didn't appear until the second verse, lifting the melody like a gentle updraft. Liam closed his eyes, leaning back in his squeaky office chair, and was transported back to the vocal booth, to that quiet, sacred space where he had sung to his mother’s memory. The recording had captured it all: the ache, the hope, the quiet tremor of unshed tears. The final, cracked note hung in the air and faded to silence, and Liam sat completely still for a full minute, a single tear tracing a path down his cheek before he hastily wiped it away, his chest tight with an emotion that was equal parts grief and gratitude.

That evening, he went to Claire's. The three of them, Liam, Claire, and a wildly excited Leo, huddled around his laptop in the living room like conspirators. He played 'Tenderness' first. Leo, who had been bouncing on the sofa, instantly launched into a frantic, flailing dance, using a cushion as an air guitar during the horn solos.
