Claire just watched the screen, her hand over her mouth, her eyes shining with tears of pure, unadulterated pride. "Liam, it's... it's a proper record," she whispered, as if she couldn't quite believe it. Then he played 'A Change Is Gonna Come'. The effect was immediate. Leo’s dancing ceased. He sat down quietly beside his mum, his usual whirlwind energy stilled by the song's solemn power. Claire’s silent tears began to fall freely, and she reached out and squeezed his hand, a fierce, protective grip that said everything. There were no grand pronouncements, just a shared, sacred silence in the song’s aftermath, a family listening to its own heart.

The next day, he went to his dad's. He didn't make a big announcement. He just walked into the living room where his dad was watching the afternoon racing and placed a small Bluetooth speaker on the coffee table. "Just wanted you to hear this, Dad," he said, and pressed play. His dad didn't move from his armchair, his gaze remaining on the television where silent, brightly coloured horses were parading in a paddock. He didn't seem to be listening. 'Tenderness' filled the quiet room, its power and passion a stark contrast to the room's dusty, muted stillness. Then 'Change' began. As the opening chords played, Liam saw his dad's hand, resting on the arm of the chair, subtly begin to tap in time with the slow, deliberate rhythm. His gaze drifted from the television to a spot on the wall, a place of memory. He remained completely still until the very last note faded. The ticking of the mantelpiece clock was the only sound. "It's good," his dad said finally, his voice gruff. He cleared his throat. "Clear as a bell. You can hear all the words." He picked up the TV remote. "Your mother would have liked that." It was all he said, but it was more than enough.

On Saturday morning, he got the call. The Biscuit Tin was ready. He took a bus to the garage on the industrial estate, a cavernous, oil-scented workshop run by a gnarled mechanic named Frank who looked like he had been assembled from spare engine parts. "Right," Frank grunted, wiping his hands on a rag that had seen better decades. "Your big end was shot. Skimmed the head, new gaskets, new water pump. Had to rebuild half the carburettor out of bits I had from an old Cortina." He looked at Liam with a kind of weary pity. "She's a wreck, this thing. But she's got a bit of heart." He handed Liam the keys. "Don't go thrashing her." Liam got into the familiar, worn driver's seat. He turned the key. The engine coughed once, then caught, settling not into its usual death-rattle, but into a steady, healthier thrum. The violent shaking was gone, but it wasn't silent. It still had its voice, a distinctive, gravelly rumble. It sounded like a grizzled old bluesman who'd given up whiskey but still smoked sixty a day.

He drove away from the garage, the car feeling more responsive, more alive. He merged onto the Chesterfield bypass, accelerating with a smoothness he hadn't felt in years. The sun was bright, the sky was a deep, cloudless blue, and the road was clear. He plugged his phone into the car's crackly stereo system and, for the first time, played his own finished songs in the car that had served as his first rehearsal room. As his own voice, clear and strong, filled the small, rattling space, a profound sense of rightness settled over him. The car was healed. He was healed. He was the Sculling Soulman, driving his beloved, battered Biscuit Tin into the wide, unknown territory of the rest of his life, the road ahead shimmering with possibility.

Summer arrived in earnest, laying a thick, warm blanket over the Derbyshire hills and turning the water of the Chesterfield Canal a deep, lazy green. Liam’s life, which had once been a rigid, monochrome routine of work and training, was now saturated with colour and complexity. His newfound local fame was a strange, low-level hum in the background of his days. He couldn’t go for a pint in town or do a weekly shop without someone stopping him to talk about ‘the show’, their praise a warm but slightly discomfiting reminder of his public vulnerability. He was no longer just Liam Kenna; he was a story people told each other, a piece of shared local pride.

Claire, revelling in her self-appointed role as his manager and publicist, insisted he had to make a return to the place where it had all started: the open mic night at The Rutland Arms. Liam was hesitant. The thought of performing there again felt different. Before, it had been a secret act of courage, a quiet test in a room full of strangers. Now, he knew the room would not be full of strangers. It would be full of people who had come specifically to see him, their expectations shaped by a dramatic, televised performance. The pressure felt immense, and he almost backed out, but Claire was relentless. “It’s a thank you,” she’d insisted. “To the pub, to the people who supported you. You owe them a song, you big lump.”

The Tuesday night he walked into the pub, the air was thick with anticipation. It was packed to the rafters, a buzzing, sweaty, cheerful crowd that spilled out into the beer garden. The usual handful of hopeful performers and their patient friends had been swallowed by a sea of familiar faces from every corner of his life. He saw his dad in a corner, nursing a pint, deep in an uncharacteristically animated conversation with Mark from the rowing club. He saw Mrs. Evans from the corner shop, and Frank the mechanic, who gave him a gruff nod. It felt less like a gig and more like a surprise party he was expected to provide the entertainment for. When the host, a genial man named Phil with a magnificent beard, called his name, a roar went up that made the glasses on the bar rattle.

He walked to the small, makeshift stage, his heart thumping a nervous rhythm against his ribs. He didn't bring a big production. He just nodded to the house guitarist, a talented player he'd spoken to earlier, and they began the gentle, soulful introduction to Bill Withers’ ‘Lovely Day’. He chose it deliberately. It wasn't a showstopper; it wasn't a cry of pain or a desperate plea. It was a simple, joyful expression of gratitude. As he began to sing, a hush fell over the rowdy pub. He wasn't trying to impress anyone. He was just singing to his friends, to his neighbours, to his town. He looked out at the faces in the crowd, saw them smiling, saw them mouthing the words along with him. He sang the famous, impossibly long note in the middle of the song, holding it with the lung capacity of a national-level rower, and the crowd went wild, cheering him on, their energy lifting him, carrying him. When the song finished, the applause was warm, genuine, and deeply personal. It was the sound of belonging.

He stayed for the rest of the night, sipping a pint of ale, enjoying the anonymity that had returned now his ‘turn’ was over. He listened to the other performers—a nervous young woman with a beautiful folk voice, a grizzled old bluesman on a harmonica—with a new appreciation for their courage. As he was getting ready to leave, a woman approached him, her face vaguely familiar. She was older, with intelligent, sharp eyes and a cascade of silver hair. "Liam Kenna?" she asked, her voice quiet but clear. "My name is Eleanor Vance. I help organise the Edale Folk & Blues Festival." The name registered immediately. It was one of the most respected small festivals in the North of England, a curated event known for its authenticity and high-quality musicianship. "I was here tonight," she continued. "A friend told me to come. I don't usually book acts based on TV competitions; they're often all flash and no substance. But what you have... it's genuine. It's honest." She handed him a business card. "We have a spot on the main stage, Saturday afternoon. It’s a paid slot. We’d be honoured if you’d consider it."

Liam stared at the card in his hand, the embossed letters feeling heavy and significant. The Edale Festival. It wasn't a competition. It was an invitation to be considered a real artist, to share a bill with musicians he deeply admired. The thought was so overwhelming he felt dizzy. "Thank you," he stammered. "I... I'd have to check my schedule." Eleanor Vance smiled, a knowing, patient smile. "I imagine you would. Your rowing schedule, I mean. The festival is the last weekend in July." The words hit Liam with the force of a physical blow. The last weekend in July. It was the same weekend as the Henley Royal Regatta, the most prestigious, most iconic, most important event in the British rowing calendar. For a competitive rower, Henley wasn't just another race; it was the ultimate goal, the culmination of a year's, or even a lifetime's, work. To be selected to race there was the pinnacle of the sport.

He drove home in The Biscuit Tin, the familiar rattle of the engine a counterpoint to the frantic buzzing in his mind. The old conflict, which he thought he had resolved, had returned with a vengeance, bigger and more complex than before. This wasn't a choice between a training camp and a TV final. This was a choice between the two highest peaks of his two separate worlds. To race at Henley was the rower's ultimate dream. To play on the main stage at Edale was a musician's dream he hadn't even dared to have. The two dreams could not coexist. The house of cards Claire had built for him for the final had been a one-time miracle; there was no way to be in two such demanding places, hundreds of miles apart, on the same weekend. He had to choose.

The next day, he found Dave by the boat racks, meticulously polishing an oar. Liam knew he had to address it head-on. "Coach," he began, his voice steady. "I've been offered a slot at the Edale Festival." Dave stopped polishing, but didn't look at him. "Right," he said, his tone neutral. "When is it?" Liam took a breath. "The last weekend of July." Dave slowly placed the oar down and finally turned to face him, his expression unreadable. "Henley," he said. It wasn't a question. "They're paying you?" Liam nodded. "It's a proper gig." Dave picked up his rag again, turning his attention back to the oar, his movements slow and deliberate. "Well, Kenna," he said, his voice a low gravelly rumble that seemed to come from the centre of the earth. "Looks like you have to decide what you are. Are you a professional rower who sings a bit? Or are you a professional singer who messes about in boats?" He didn't say another word, but the weight of the choice, and of his coach’s unspoken disappointment, settled on Liam’s shoulders, heavy and suffocating. He walked home, opened his calendar, and stared at the two dates, circled in red, on opposing pages of his life. The choice was stark, brutal, and entirely his.

The blade sliced the water, but the sound was no longer a clean rip in the silence. It was a dull thud, the sound of an obligation being met. The canal, his timeless confidante, felt different now, its surface reflecting not the dawn sky but the stark, binary choice that had fractured his world. Henley or Edale. The past or the future. The man he had built or the man he was discovering. Dave's words echoed with every stroke, a brutal, unforgiving rhythm that drowned out any melody. *Are you a professional rower who sings a bit? Or are you a professional singer who messes about in boats?* The question wasn't about scheduling; it was an interrogation of his very soul, and the water offered no answers, only a cold, indifferent reflection of his own turmoil.

For a decade, this rhythm had been the answer to everything. When he was stressed, he rowed. When he was grieving, he rowed. When he needed to feel strong, he rowed. The simple, punishing mechanics of the stroke had always been enough to scour his mind clean. But now, the magic was gone. The motion felt hollow, the burn in his muscles just a familiar ache, not a cleansing fire. He found himself looking at the banks, at the familiar trees and the distant smudge of the crooked spire, with the eyes of a tourist. He was a visitor in his own life, a ghost going through the motions. The thought of Henley, which should have been a blazing sun on his horizon, now felt like a colossal, crushing weight. It represented the culmination of everything he had worked for, the respect of his peers, the approval of his coach. To turn away from it felt like a betrayal, an act of profound self-sabotage. But the thought of turning down Edale, of letting that invitation to a new world expire, felt like a slow, quiet death. It was the closing of a door he had only just found the courage to open.

He tried to talk to Claire about it, but the conversation felt like a foregone conclusion. They sat in her small, chaotic garden, the late afternoon sun casting long shadows, while Leo chased a football around them. Liam laid out the impossible choice, and Claire, ever the pragmatist, saw no dilemma at all. "Liam, it's not a choice," she said, her tone firm, as if explaining a simple sum to a struggling pupil. "Henley is a race you've already won a dozen times in a dozen different boats. It's more of the same. More aching muscles, more 5 a.m. starts, more of Dave grunting at you. Edale... Edale is a beginning. It's a stage full of people who want to hear *you*, not just watch your back while you pull an oar. It's the world opening up for you. Rowing is what you're good at. Singing is what you love. When do you get to choose what you love?" Her logic was flawless, her passion infectious, but it didn't ease the knot in his stomach. She saw it as a simple equation of head versus heart. She didn't feel the weight of ten years of loyalty, the phantom ache of blisters on his hands, or the heavy burden of Dave's conditional respect.

The conflict followed him home, a constant, low-level hum of anxiety. He stood in his living room, staring at the mantelpiece, a museum of his former life. He picked up his national championship medal, its weight familiar and substantial in his palm. He remembered the feeling of that win: the lung-searing agony of the final sprint, the explosion of relief at the finish line, the shared, exhausted triumph with his crewmates. It was a brutal, powerful joy. Then his gaze fell on the small, unassuming business card from Eleanor Vance, which he had propped against his mother's photograph. Edale. He imagined standing on that stage, not with a crew, but alone with a guitar and a microphone. He imagined the silence of a listening crowd in an open field, the sun setting behind the Peak District hills. He imagined the connection, the vulnerability, the quiet, profound joy of sharing a story through a song. It was a different kind of victory, one that couldn't be measured by a stopwatch.

He knew who he needed to talk to. He drove to his dad's house on a Thursday evening, finding him in the greenhouse at the bottom of the garden, tending to his tomato plants. The air was warm and smelled of earth and growing things. Liam didn't know how to begin. He ended up just stating the facts, his voice sounding flat and emotionless in the quiet greenhouse. "I've been invited to race at Henley," he said, pinching a stray leaf from a plant. "And I've been asked to sing at the Edale festival. They're on the same weekend." His dad continued his work, carefully tying a sagging stem to a cane. He didn't speak for a long time, his movements slow and methodical. "Henley," he said finally, the name itself a recognition of its importance. "That's the big one, isn't it? The one with the blazers." "Yeah, Dad. That's the one." "And this festival?" "That's a big one, too. For music." His dad finished tying the knot and straightened up, wiping his earthy hands on his trousers. He looked at Liam, his gaze direct and clear. "When you were a lad," he began, "you and your mother, you were always singing. She'd be in the kitchen, you'd be in the living room, singing back and forth to each other. I never understood half of it. But I understood the look on her face." He paused, looking past Liam, back into a memory. "When you won your first big race, she was proud. Fit to burst. Told everyone she met. But when she heard you sing... proper sing, like at your cousin's wedding... she didn't just look proud. She looked... happy. Like a part of her she thought was lost had turned up in you." He picked up his watering can. "There's a difference between what makes you proud and what makes you happy, lad. You've spent a long time making other people proud. Might be time to do what makes you happy."

The simple words, spoken without sentiment but with a profound, quiet truth, landed like a key turning in a lock. It was permission. Not just from his dad, but from the memory of his mother, from a part of himself he had kept quiet for too long. He drove home, the conflict gone, replaced by a calm, terrifying certainty. The decision was made. He sat at his kitchen table and composed an email to Eleanor Vance, his fingers moving with a newfound confidence. He accepted her offer. Then, he picked up the phone. The harder call was to Dave. But he knew it couldn't be a call. It had to be face to face.

The next morning, he found Dave in his office, staring at the crew lists pinned to the corkboard. Liam stood in the doorway, his heart a slow, heavy drum. He didn't wait for an invitation. "Coach, I've made my decision," he said, his voice clear and steady. "I won't be going to Henley. I'm going to sing at the festival." Dave didn't turn around. He remained staring at the board, his back a rigid wall of disapproval. "I see," he said, his voice cold and flat. "So you've decided. You're a singer." "No," Liam said, taking a step into the room. "I'm a man who is going to sing at a festival. It doesn't mean I'm not a rower. It just means I have to do this." Dave finally turned, and the look on his face was not anger, but a deep, weary disappointment that was infinitely worse. "Rowing isn't something you just 'do', Kenna. Not at this level. It's everything. It demands everything. You can't be a part-time contender. It's all or nothing. I thought you understood that." He turned back to the corkboard, took a pen from his desk, and drew a single, thick, black line through Liam Kenna's name on the Henley crew list. The sound of the pen scratching across the paper was the only sound in the room, a brutal, final act of severance. "The squad is my responsibility," Dave said, his back still to him. "And the squad needs athletes who are fully committed. I wish you luck with your... music." The word was dropped like a stone. It was a dismissal. Liam stood for a moment, the finality of the act washing over him. He had made his choice, and the consequences were real and immediate. He felt a profound sense of loss, a grief for the life he was leaving behind. But underneath it, buried deep, was a flicker of something else. A terrifying, exhilarating spark of freedom. "Thank you, coach," he said quietly to the man's unrelenting back. Then he turned and walked out of the boathouse, leaving a decade of his life behind him, stepping out into the bright, uncertain light of a future he would have to write himself.

The boathouse door clicked shut behind him, a sound no louder than a snapping twig, yet it echoed in his mind with the finality of a prison gate slamming. Liam stood in the car park, the morning sun feeling unnaturally bright and hostile on his face. The familiar, comforting scent of river water and damp earth was replaced by the acrid smell of tarmac and exhaust fumes. He felt profoundly out of place, a deep-sea creature suddenly stranded on a sun-bleached beach. His car keys felt heavy and useless in his hand. He couldn’t get in The Biscuit Tin, couldn't drive away. That would be an escape, an admission of defeat. He needed to walk, to feel the solid ground beneath his feet, to process the tectonic shift that had just occurred. He turned not towards the road, but towards the canal towpath, the path he had pounded into submission on a thousand pre-dawn runs.

He walked for miles, a man in a trance. The path was different from this perspective, at this time of day. It was alive with dog walkers, cheerful cyclists, and families feeding the ducks. They moved through a world of casual leisure, oblivious to the fact that they were treading on his church, his battlefield. He was an observer now, an outsider looking in. He saw a novice crew from the club out on the water, their movements clumsy and uncoordinated, their coach shouting encouragement from a bicycle. A wave of something that felt painfully like pity, both for them and for himself, washed over him. They were at the beginning of the journey he had just been ejected from. He watched them until they were out of sight, then sat on a cold stone bench, the same bench where Dave had once told him he had the makings of a champion. He stared at the slow-moving, indifferent water, the surface a murky green-brown, no longer a pristine track but just a neglected waterway cutting through the heart of the country. He had given it ten years of his life, his sweat and his soul, and it had taken it all without comment. It owed him nothing. The freedom he had felt a flicker of in Dave’s office was, out here in the open, a vast, terrifying emptiness.

He ended up at Claire's, drawn by an instinct for sanctuary. She opened the door, took one look at his pale, drawn face, and her triumphant smile faltered. "Oh, Liam," she said, her voice soft with a sympathy that was almost his undoing. She led him into the kitchen and made him a mug of tea so strong it could have dissolved the spoon. He told her what had happened, the words coming out in a flat, detached monotone. He told her about the black line Dave had drawn through his name, the finality of it, the cold dismissal. Claire listened, her expression hardening from sympathy to a fierce, protective anger. "Good," she said, when he had finished, slamming the sugar bowl down on the table. "Good riddance to him. And to all of it. Liam, that place was a cage, and you were too big for it. You just couldn't see it. He didn't kick you out. You outgrew him. You outgrew the whole damn sport." Her certainty was a comfort, a warm blanket thrown over his shivering shoulders, but it didn't quite reach the cold spot deep inside him, the place that was grieving the loss of his tribe, the death of the man he had been.

The next morning, the digital alarm on his bedside table blared its shrill, familiar summons at 5:00 a.m. For a fraction of a second, his body responded with the ingrained muscle memory of a decade. His legs tensed, his mind snapping into a state of pre-dawn readiness, already calculating the air temperature and the river conditions. Then, reality hit him like a physical blow. He didn't have to go. There was no water waiting, no boat to rig, no coach to appease. The purpose that had dragged him from his bed every morning for ten years was gone. He reached out and slapped the snooze button, but the silence that followed was more jarring than the alarm had been. It was a cavernous, empty silence, filled with the ghost of a life he no longer lived. He lay in the darkness, feeling the absence of the familiar pre-training aches in his muscles. His body felt alien, rested and unprepared for a battle that was no longer his to fight. The freedom he had chosen felt, in the stark reality of this new, unstructured dawn, like a profound and terrifying loneliness.

He eventually got up, not to row, but because lying in bed felt like a surrender. He made tea and sat in his quiet living room as the pale grey light of dawn seeped through the curtains. The house felt too big, the morning too long. The empty hours stretched before him, a vast, uncharted territory. His gaze fell on his guitar, propped in the corner. It looked less like a hobby now and more like a tool, a piece of equipment for a job he had only just started. He picked it up, the smooth wood of the neck cool and solid in his hand. He didn't play a song. He just played chords, simple, open chords, letting them ring out and fill the silence. E major. A major. G. He wasn't performing, wasn't practicing. He was just making a sound, a deliberate act of filling the void, of replacing the old rhythm with a new one. The squeak of the oarlocks was gone. The rhythmic gasp of his own breath on the water was gone. There was only this: the vibration of six steel strings against his fingertips, a small, hopeful noise in the quiet of a new day.

The official contract from the Edale festival arrived in his inbox a few days later, a stark, professional document that made it all terrifyingly real. A forty-five-minute set on the main stage. He scrolled through his phone's music library, a collection of beloved songs that now looked like a dauntingly small pool of material. He could play for fifteen, maybe twenty minutes, but forty-five? He needed more songs, more variety, more substance. He needed a band. The thought was paralyzing. He was a solitary creature, a single sculler used to the monastic discipline of training alone. The idea of collaborating, of relying on other people, of leading a group, was entirely alien. But the choice had been made, and the path led forward, not back. He thought of the open mic night, of the easy confidence of the house guitarist. Phil, the host, had called him Jamie. With a sense of leaping into the void, Liam found the number for The Rutland Arms and asked for him.

He met Jamie in a different pub, a musician's haunt in the centre of Sheffield with sticky floors and a jukebox full of classic rock. Jamie was younger than him by at least ten years, with bright, intelligent eyes and the restless energy of someone whose fingers were always itching to play. Liam, feeling like a giant in the small, crowded room, explained the situation, the words feeling clunky and inadequate. He felt like a fraud, a rower playing dress-up in a musician's world. But Jamie listened with an infectious enthusiasm, his eyes lighting up when Liam mentioned Edale. "Mate, that's huge! Their main stage is legendary. So, you need a band?" Liam nodded, feeling a blush creep up his neck. "I don't know the first thing about it." Jamie grinned, a wide, easy smile. "Don't worry about that. That's the easy part. I know a rhythm section that's tighter than a submarine door. A bassist, Steve, and a drummer, Chloe. They're amazing. We've been looking for a proper singer, someone with real pipes, not another indie kid mumbling into his fringe." The casual compliment landed with surprising force. *A proper singer.* It was a validation from a world he was desperate to belong to. "Let's have a jam," Jamie said, pulling a notebook from his pocket. "Let's see what we can build."

Their first rehearsal was in a dingy, soundproofed room above a Sheffield pub, a space that smelled of stale beer, old carpets, and electricity. It was chaotic and loud. Chloe, the drummer, sat behind a battered kit, a whirlwind of focused energy, while Steve, the bassist, stood quietly, a calm anchor in the sonic storm, his fingers dancing effortlessly on the fretboard. Liam felt utterly out of his depth. He was used to silence and solitude, to the clean, straight lines of a race course. This was a messy, collaborative art, a conversation shouted in a language of chords and drum fills. They tried 'Try a Little Tenderness' first, and it was a train wreck. Liam was used to singing it with a polished house band that followed his lead; this was different. This was a negotiation. They stopped and started, the song falling apart as they struggled to find a common rhythm. Liam felt a surge of panic, a feeling of total incompetence. But Jamie just laughed. "Alright, let's take it from the build-up. Chloe, watch him. He sings like a boxer. Follow his breathing." They tried again. Jamie hit the chords, Chloe came in with a thunderous, rolling fill, and Steve locked into a groove that was a solid, pulsing heartbeat. Liam took a breath and sang, and this time, the band was with him. They weren't just backing him; they were lifting him, pushing him, answering his vocal lines with their own musical declarations. He felt the raw power of it, a force far greater than his own, a surge of energy that was like catching a perfect stroke with three other rowers in perfect sync. It was a different kind of boat, a different kind of crew, but the feeling of shared, explosive power was the same.

He drove home from the rehearsal late that night, his ears ringing and his throat raw from pushing his voice over the joyful noise of a full band. The Biscuit Tin’s radio was off, the silence a welcome relief. He was tired, but it was a new kind of tired, a creative exhaustion that buzzed with energy rather than leaden fatigue. He pulled over at his usual vantage point, the quiet lane overlooking the sleeping town. For weeks, this spot had been a place of turmoil and difficult decisions. Tonight, it felt different. He looked out at the familiar pattern of orange streetlights and dark rooftops, the crooked spire a steadfast silhouette against a starry sky. He thought of the rowing club, of Dave, of the black line through his name. The ache of that loss was still there, a faint, phantom limb of a past life. But it was no longer the dominant feeling. It was being replaced by the thrill of the new, the terror and excitement of the path he was now on. He was no longer a rower mourning his past. He was a singer, and he had a festival to prepare for. He had a band to lead. He put the car in gear and drove towards home, a new set of rhythms playing in his head, a new set of proving grounds waiting.

The weeks leading up to the Edale festival took on a rhythm of their own, a vibrant, chaotic cadence that was a world away from the metronomic precision of his rowing life. Liam’s mornings were no longer defined by the shrill scream of a 5 a.m. alarm and the cold shock of canal water. He still rose early, the discipline of a decade too deeply ingrained to abandon, but his purpose had shifted. Instead of the towpath, he took to the trails of the Linacre Woods, running not against a stopwatch but for the simple, burning pleasure of it, his lungs expanding, his heart hammering out a steady beat. He was still an athlete, but his body was no longer just an engine for propulsion; it was an instrument he was learning to tune for a different kind of endurance, the stamina to hold a note, to command a stage, to give a forty-five-minute performance his all. He ran with music in his headphones, not as a distraction, but as a study, dissecting arrangements, internalising rhythms, his mind a constant, buzzing workshop of musical ideas.

The rehearsal space above the pub became their boathouse, their proving ground. It was a cramped, stuffy room that perpetually smelled of the ghosts of spilled beer and forgotten cigarettes, the walls covered in egg cartons that did a questionable job of soundproofing. But within those four walls, a kind of magic began to happen. The initial chaos of four musicians trying to find a common language slowly coalesced into a dynamic, a conversation. Liam, used to the clear, hierarchical structure of a rowing squad, struggled at first with the messy democracy of a band. He found it difficult to articulate the sounds he heard in his head, often falling back on the only vocabulary he had. “It needs more… drive here,” he’d say, gesturing with his hands. “Like the beginning of the stroke, that first big leg push.” Jamie, ever the enthusiastic translator, would grin. “You mean you want the bass and drums to really lean into the downbeat? Hit it hard?” And Chloe, from behind her fortress of cymbals, would unleash a thunderous fill that was exactly the right kind of power, making Liam break into a grateful smile.

They built their setlist piece by piece, an exercise in shared archaeology, digging up classic soul and R&B gems and breathing new life into them. They transformed Wilson Pickett’s ‘In the Midnight Hour’ into a gritty, blues-stomp, and found a swampy, menacing groove in Bill Withers’ ‘Who Is He (And What Is He to You)?’. Steve, the quiet bassist, proved to be their secret weapon, a walking encyclopaedia of music who would suggest a subtle chord change or a different bassline that would unlock an entire song. But their biggest breakthrough came not from a cover, but from a moment of pure, unplanned creation. During a break, while Liam was sipping a bottle of water, Jamie started playing a simple, melancholic guitar riff, a phrase that felt like a question mark hanging in the dusty air. Without thinking, Liam began to hum along, a low, soulful melody taking shape over the chords. The words that emerged were simple, drawn from the landscape of his old life. *“Water like glass, a grey morning sky… another mile to go before the sun gets high…”*

The room fell silent. Jamie’s fingers stilled on the strings. Chloe and Steve looked at him, their expressions a mixture of surprise and intense interest. "What was that, mate?" Jamie asked, his voice soft. Liam felt a hot blush of self-consciousness, the feeling of having been caught in a private moment. "Nothing. Just messing about," he mumbled, turning back to his water. "No," Steve said, his quiet voice cutting through the awkwardness. "That was something. Play the riff again, Jamie." Jamie obliged, and this time, Liam, nudged by their expectant silence, sang the lines again, his voice hesitant at first, then growing in confidence. Chloe joined in with a soft, subtle beat on the ride cymbal, a gentle pulse like a distant train. Steve added a low, looping bassline that gave the melody an anchor. It wasn't a song yet. It was a sketch, a feeling, a fragment of a new story. But it was *his*. For the first time, he wasn't just interpreting someone else's truth; he was beginning to articulate his own. They worked on it for an hour, building a structure, finding a chorus, the music flowing from a place of genuine, collaborative excitement. They called it 'Canal Song'.

The world outside the rehearsal room continued to turn, and one Saturday afternoon, while loading groceries into the boot of Claire’s car, Liam saw a familiar figure jogging towards him. It was Mark, his old rowing partner, his face leaner and more strained than Liam remembered. The encounter was awkward, a meeting of ghosts from different timelines. "Liam! Blimey, didn't recognise you without an oar in your hand," Mark panted, slowing to a stop. "Heard you're a rock star now. How's it going?" The question was friendly, but tinged with a curiosity that felt like a probe. "It's going alright," Liam said, leaning against the car. "We're playing Edale in a few weeks." "Edale, right," Mark nodded, his eyes flicking away. "We're at Henley next weekend. Dave's got us on a brutal schedule. Killing us. We could have used your weight in the eight." The words hung in the air, a casual statement that landed like a small, sharp stone. A pang of guilt, of nostalgia for the simple camaraderie of the crew, hit Liam unexpectedly. "Good luck," Liam said, and was surprised by the sincerity in his own voice. "I hope you win." Mark gave him a strange look, a mixture of gratitude and confusion. "Cheers, mate. You too. Break a leg, or whatever it is you lot say." He jogged off, leaving Liam standing in the supermarket car park, feeling the last, fraying thread connecting him to his old life finally snap.

The final rehearsal before the festival was less a practice and more a declaration of intent. They ran through the entire forty-five-minute set, from the explosive opening of 'Hold On, I'm Comin'' to the quiet, soulful encore of 'Canal Song'. They were no longer four separate musicians; they were a single entity, a tight, powerful unit that breathed and moved as one. They crashed through the final chords of their last song, the sound ringing out in the small, sweaty room, and ended in a sudden, breathless silence. They looked at each other, grinning, exhausted, and united by the shared, electric thrill of creation. They had done the work. They had found their sound. They were a band. "Well," Jamie said, wiping sweat from his brow with the back of his hand. "I reckon we're ready to scare some folk singers." Liam laughed, a deep, easy sound of pure joy. He felt a familiar ache in his muscles and a satisfying rawness in his throat. It was the feeling of having given everything, of having left it all on the floor. He was ready. He was no longer a rower who sang, or a singer who used to row. He was Liam Kenna, and he had a festival to play.

The air in the Hope Valley tasted different. It was cleaner, sharper, scented with wild thyme, damp earth, and the distant, enticing aroma of woodsmoke and fried onions. Gone was the familiar, brackish tang of the canal; this was the air of mountains and open spaces, of freedom and possibility. The Edale festival was not just an event; it was a temporary, sprawling city of canvas and colour, pitched in a vast green bowl of a valley and thrumming with a bohemian, life-affirming energy. Colourful flags snapped in the breeze, and the low, rolling thunder of a distant soundcheck mixed with the laughter of children and the gentle cadence of a hundred different conversations. Liam, navigating the crowded, slightly muddy pathways with his bandmates, felt a world away from the manicured lawns and rigid etiquette of a regatta. This was a gathering of tribes, but the uniforms were tie-dye and worn denim, not lycra and club blazers, and the competition was a joyful battle of melodies, not a grim war of attrition against a stopwatch.

They made their way to the main stage, a colossal structure of steel scaffolding and black canvas that seemed to have landed from another planet in the middle of the picturesque valley. It was far bigger than Liam had imagined, a huge, yawning mouth that would soon demand to be filled with sound. Standing at the side of it, looking out at the empty field where thousands of people would soon gather, he felt a familiar, cold spike of fear, a dizzying sense of vertigo. But it was different from the solitary terror of the Voice of the Peaks final. He wasn't alone. Jamie clapped him on the shoulder, a wide, excited grin on his face. “Bit bigger than The Rutland, eh?” Chloe was methodically taping her fingers, her expression one of intense, professional focus, while Steve was quietly tuning his bass, a small, calm smile on his lips. They were a crew, facing their Henley, and the shared sense of purpose was a powerful anchor against the rising tide of his nerves.

Backstage was a controlled, friendly chaos. Roadies in black t-shirts moved with practiced efficiency, coiling cables and checking microphones. Seasoned musicians with faces like road maps and guitars that bore the scars of a thousand gigs nodded a hello as they passed. There was no glitter, no hairspray, just a deep, unspoken respect for the craft. Liam found his family huddled by a catering tent, looking slightly overwhelmed but thrilled. Leo was staring, wide-eyed, at a man with a beard down to his chest who was playing a mandolin. Claire hugged him tightly, her nervous energy a vibrating current. “You okay? You’re not going to be sick, are you?” she whispered fiercely. Liam shook his head, a smile touching his lips. And then he saw his dad, standing slightly apart from the backstage bustle, holding a plastic cup of tea and looking distinctly out of place in his sensible slacks and clean windbreaker. He looked at Liam, then at the huge, empty stage, then back again. He didn’t offer words of encouragement. He just held out a bottle of water he’d been keeping for him. “You’ll be needing this,” was all he said. Liam took it, their hands brushing, the simple, practical gesture a more profound expression of support than any speech could have been.

The forty-five minutes before their set was a blur. They were led to the stage by a cheerful woman with a clipboard. The field was no longer empty; it was a vast, sprawling sea of humanity, a kaleidoscope of picnic blankets, camping chairs, and expectant faces under the bright afternoon sun. This was no darkened auditorium where the audience was an anonymous void. He could see them. He could see their faces, their expressions of curiosity, their smiles. There was nowhere to hide. He took his place at the centre microphone, the stage feeling as wide as a football pitch. He glanced back at Chloe, who gave him a sharp, confident nod. To his left, Steve gave him a thumbs-up. To his right, Jamie grinned, hit a single, loud, defiant chord on his guitar, and the sound exploded from the giant speakers, a declaration that they had arrived. And then Chloe’s drums kicked in, a thunderous, irresistible beat, and they launched into the explosive opening of ‘Hold On, I’m Comin’’.

For the first few moments, Liam was just a passenger, carried along by the sheer power of the band. The sound was immense, a physical force that vibrated through the floorboards of the stage and into the soles of his feet. He opened his mouth and let his voice ride on top of it, a raw, joyful roar that felt like a release of every ounce of pent-up energy and anxiety he possessed. He saw the crowd react, saw their heads turn, saw a ripple of surprise and interest spread through the field. He saw people who had been lying on their blankets sit up, their attention captured. He wasn't just a big man with a surprisingly soulful voice anymore; he was the frontman of a tight, powerful, blues-drenched rock and roll band, and they were a force to be reckoned with. They crashed through the first two songs, a high-octane medley that demanded a physical response, and by the third song, a slinky, groove-laden version of ‘Who Is He (And What Is He to You)?’, a space had opened up at the front of the crowd, and people were dancing, a fluid, joyful mass moving to the rhythm they were creating.

He felt himself relax into it, the performance becoming a conversation, not a test. He moved with the music, feeding off the energy of his bandmates, catching Jamie’s eye and grinning as the guitarist unleashed a blistering solo. He watched Chloe, a blur of motion and concentration, driving the beat forward with a ferocious intensity. He felt Steve’s bassline, a solid, unshakeable foundation that allowed him the freedom to soar. They were a single, living organism, speaking a language of pure, unfiltered emotion. And then, it was time. The high-energy songs faded, and a quiet anticipation settled over the field. Jamie switched to his acoustic guitar, playing the simple, questioning riff they had discovered in the rehearsal room. Liam stepped closer to the microphone, the vast crowd seeming to lean in as one. “This is a new song,” he said, his voice quiet but carrying across the field. “It’s one of ours. It’s about the place I’m from, and the life I used to know. It’s called ‘Canal Song’.”

He sang, and the story of his old life, of the grey dawns and the silent, solitary work, filled the warm summer air of the Hope Valley. The lyrics were a watercolour painting of a world he had left behind, full of images of tearing silk and misty mornings, of aching muscles and the relentless rhythm of the stroke. He sang not with regret, but with a deep, tender understanding, a farewell to the man he had been. The crowd fell utterly silent, a field of thousands holding a collective breath. They weren’t just listening to a song; they were hearing a confession, a testimony, a story of transformation. In the quietest moments of the song, the only sound was his voice, the gentle strum of the guitar, and the whisper of the wind in the festival banners. He was laying his soul bare, not in a theatre under the glare of competitive lights, but in a field, under an open sky, in front of a community of strangers. It was the most honest thing he had ever done.

When the final, gentle chord faded into the afternoon air, the silence held for a beat, a moment of profound, shared resonance. Then, the applause came. It wasn’t the explosive, percussive roar of the TV final. It was a wave, a swell of deep, heartfelt appreciation that grew and grew, washing over the stage. He saw Eleanor Vance at the side of the stage, her arms crossed, a small, profound smile on her face. They finished their set with a triumphant, joyful rendition of ‘Lovely Day’, the entire field singing the chorus back at him, their voices joining his in a huge, harmonious choir. He walked off stage, his legs trembling, his shirt soaked through with sweat, his throat raw, and fell into the waiting, triumphant hugs of his band. They had done it. They had flown.

Later, he stood in the middle of the crowd with his family, just another face in the sea of festival-goers, watching another band on the main stage. The setting sun painted the clouds in shades of pink and orange, the same colours he used to see mirrored on the surface of the canal at dawn. Leo was asleep on his shoulder, a small, warm weight of pure contentment. Claire was leaning against him, her face glowing with happiness. His dad stood beside him, holding a plastic cup of beer, watching the band on stage with a look of quiet concentration. During a break in the music, his dad turned to him. He didn't speak. He just looked at Liam, a long, searching look, and then he raised his plastic cup in a small, almost imperceptible toast. It was a gesture of acknowledgement, of respect, of a quiet, hard-won pride. Liam raised his own bottle of water in return, a silent understanding passing between them. Miles away, in the manicured grounds of Henley-on-Thames, boats were being racked, medals were being awarded, and a life he once thought was his everything was concluding without him. He felt no loss, no regret. He was here, in a field in Derbyshire, surrounded by his family and a new tribe, his ears ringing with music, his heart full. He had found his finish line. It wasn't a line on the water. It was a stage, a song, and a new, wide-open horizon.
